Unemployed people in Port Adelaide were able to find work in the lead-up to Christmas with both employers and job seekers benefiting from the initiatives in the government's white paper on employment and growth, Working Nation.

The one-thousandth vacancy was filled by Crompton and Sons, a tannery in Wingfield in my electorate. The client was a job compact placement who had been registered as unemployed since 19 January 1982. In fact, this particular person had been on unemployment benefits continuously since 25 March 1988. We celebrated that occasion most appropriately with Mr Gary Jones from Cromptons, invited guests and the very important new employee.

The involvement of business and the community in the campaign, and the publicity generated, helped raise the profile of DEET in my electorate of Port Adelaide and the initiatives of Working Nation. There is also no doubt that the contribution of the Port Adelaide Football Club was critical to the achievement of the 1,000 jobs target.

There is no doubt that in the developed world there is a chronic and endemic unemployment problem. When you analyse the last 40 years, you discover that productivity has quadrupled. We discover that capital investment has almost quadrupled. We discover that energy consumption has tripled. But—here is the real catch—the need for labour has increased by only a third.

There are different economic orthodoxies around the world that for different reasons appear incapable of solving the unemployment problem. In Europe you find high wages and high unemployment but with a safety net. In the United States you find very low wages and a lower rate of unemployment but without an adequate safety net in a situation which, according to Robert Reich, the US Secretary of Labor, is equally undesirable. Working Nation is uniquely Australian. It rejects the pathways taken by the Europeans and the North Americans.

Under Working Nation, the government has committed itself to reduce the number of unemployed, particularly the number of long-term unemployed. The government committed itself to provide a job offer to all those in the job compact. The government committed itself to introduce individual assistance through competitive case management. The government committed itself to deliver a substantial increase in entry level training places. It needs to be acknowledged that the government is well on track to achieve all of the targets set for these objectives.

In Working Nation, the nation set a target of reducing unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000. Since the release of Working Nation, the rate of unemployment has fallen from a peak of 11.2 per cent to 8.5 per cent. This is a highly significant achievement against a backdrop of increasing participation rates. In the past two years we have seen the creation of 600,000 jobs. Working Nation made the commitment to reduce the number of long-term unemployed people. This was in part through case management and in part through a guaranteed job offer to all long-term unemployed people in the job compact.

In the economic downturn of the early 1980s, interest rates, inflation and unemployment were all over 10 per cent. I am sure those on the other side well remember that. This guaranteed that the electorate would decisively reject the coalition and its failed policies of the time. In the recovery cycle that followed with a Labor government, only one in seven long-term unemployed gained employment. The ratio has in the current recovery improved dramatically for the long-term unemployed because of the initiatives of Working Nation. The fall has been close to 30 per cent—a ratio of almost one in three and a huge improvement on the one in seven ratio of the early 1980s.

Overall, unemployment numbers have fallen by close to 15 per cent in the last 12 months, as the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) said today. Youth long-term unemployment has fallen by 44 per cent in the 12 months to March this year. The number of newstart allowance recipients has fallen by 12.6 per cent in the same period.

The budget reaffirmed the government's commitment to the goals and targets of Working Nation. There will be substantial increases in funding of labour market programs, with expenditure estimated to increase from the $1.3 billion of the last financial year to $1.9 billion in the next financial year and $2 billion in 1996-97. As the member for Lyne has acknowledged in his motion before the House, the new work opportunities program is the key element of ensuring that the job compact can be delivered to all eligible job seekers, particularly if they live in areas where employment opportunities are limited.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently had sent to me a page of the Canberra City News. Under the heading `A win for Trish' I noted a story which commenced:

SPEECH.PARA: South Australian Liberal Trish Worth has had what comes rarely to a backbencher—a big win.

The `big win' concerned relates to my campaign for legislation banning female genital mutilation. It has been written up as a win because all the states, except Western Australia, have given undertakings to legislate against the practice of female genital mutilation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have now too, I think, Trish.

—I acknowledge the Attorney-General and thank him. I will still go on to say that I have reason to feel optimistic that Western Australia shall follow the other states and undertake to introduce quite specific legislation to ban this practice. It is a win for women and not `a win for Trish'. But I am glad if in a small way I facilitated the win.

PARA.TAB: My private member's motion calling for the banning of this worst type of culturally accepted assault was moved in this place on 21 February 1994. At that time I reminded the House that this assault had been practised on females by some ethnic communities for thousands of years to secure their virginity as `maidens' and their faithfulness as wives. It is a traumatic and violent attack on women and little girls which is painful, dangerous, has serious long-term effects and can cause death. A World Health Organisation report released in October last year says that at least two million women and girls are affected each year and that the practice is growing in Australia, Europe and North America.

I congratulate the former New South Wales government and the present South Australian government, both of which have already passed legislation banning female genital mutilation. In South Australia, the legislation was introduced one year and one day following my private member's motion. When speaking to the motion, I also highlighted the need for education. I said at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: Legislation must be part of the strategy to educate and promote change not only in ethnic communities but also amongst professionals including doctors, midwives, nurses, teachers, social workers, the police and courts and the general community.
There can be no stronger education or message to the international community than specific legislation.

For those women who have themselves been mutilated but who are fighting to prevent the same happening to their daughters, it will strengthen their argument with the men or grandmothers of their communities who still firmly believe in the tradition.

I am pleased that the federal government in the last budget allocated $3.46 million over the next five years towards an education program. It is my understanding that the next meeting of the Attorneys-General will be held in Perth on 14 July. I hope at that meeting Western Australia will announce—if it has not already done so—its own intention to join with the other states for a uniform approach. Should that be the case, it will be a reason to acknowledge just what can be achieved on an important human rights issue with a bipartisan approach in this place and then with cooperation between the states and the Commonwealth.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Delegation to Egypt, Israel and Spain

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the privileges we may have in this place is to represent the Australian parliament overseas. However, after three delegations—the last with you, Mr Speaker, to Egypt, Israel and Spain—I certainly appreciate the value of the professional support which is given to delegations prior to leaving and while overseas.

PARA.TAB: I therefore take this opportunity to sincerely thank the staff from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, which is now AusAID; and the Department of the Parliamentary Library. I would also like to give highly deserved recognition to the officers who accompanied the delegation and who gave so much professional and personal input. Geraldine Skinner, Pam McDonald and Anne Hazelton were outstanding in ensuring that the delegation visits were successful and meaningful and, in their very professional and unobtrusive way, attending to the needs of delegation members. It is the third time I have been on a delegation with Anne Hazelton and the second time with Geraldine Skinner; together with Pam McDonald, they are to be commended for their invaluable contribution.

Undoubtedly one of the highlights, prior to the bilateral visit to Egypt and Israel, was the opportunity—albeit a brief one—to have a private audience with His Holiness Pope John Paul II and to be guided through the Vatican museum and St Peter's Basilica.

Mr Speaker, as you are acutely aware, the Middle East remains one of the major regions of conflict in international relations. The bilateral visit to Egypt afforded me, on a first-hand basis, the opportunity to fully appreciate the peace treaty that was signed way back in 1979 between Egypt and Israel. The skills of those people responsible for that treaty should never be forgotten.

Egypt has played a significant and key role in the peace process by hosting and facilitating many meetings prior to peace negotiations between Israel and its other Arab neighbours which began in Madrid in 1991. As the delegation report which has been tabled in the House indicates, Australia is a strong supporter of the Middle East peace process and has consistently supported a comprehensive regional settlement based on the relevant UN Security Council resolutions. The major moderating role taken by Egypt in the peace process is an important element underpinning sound bilateral relations between Australia and Egypt.

The Australian parliamentary delegation's visit to Israel occurred at a most significant time for that country and for the region. We all gained insights into the domestic situation in Israel, developments in the Middle East peace process and, from an Israeli point of view, its relations with its Arab neighbours. However, there is no doubt that an enormous gap must be bridged between Israel and the Palestinians before a lasting peace can be achieved.

All members of the Australian delegation—as you yourself did, Mr Speaker—felt very deeply and with a heightened sense of awareness the enormous delicacy and complexity of Israeli-Palestinian relations and their implications for the peace process. Australia has been a long-time supporter of the Middle East peace process and is actively involved through financial assistance for Palestinian autonomy, participation in the multilateral working groups and participation in the multinational force and observers.

The day we had with the multinational force and observer in North Camp in the Sinai was both informative and enjoyable in meeting the Australian troops in command. Australians, Major General David Ferguson, Colonel McGowan, Major Crunkhorn, Matthew Robertson, and others and, in fact, everyone we met made our visit very special. We certainly gained insights into the very successful peacekeeping mission and the particularly high skills of our forces overseas. Mr Speaker, on a lighter note, I soon realised, by seeing your white face, that I was not the only person who was uncomfortable while flying in open-doored helicopters.

The subject items for the 93rd Interparliamentary Conference covered the issues of international humanitarian assistance and bioethics. I was privileged to be able to address the conference on the second major theme, namely, bioethics and its implications worldwide for human rights protection.

Mr Speaker, it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge your contribution and that of the other delegation members, Senator Paul Calvert and the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), as well as our embassy staff in Egypt, Israel, Spain and the Holy See. I would like to name them quickly: Colin McDonald, Mrs McDonald, Phillip Allars, Trudy Whitbreuk, Peter Rogers, Mrs Rogers, Bruce Lendon, Stephen Ross, Stephen Robinson, Warwick Pearson, Ricardo Zalapa, Mrs Zalapa, Radik Divis, and Bill O'Brien in the Holy See. They all assisted in a very professional manner in ensuring that the delegation visits and meetings were highly successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 December 1993 I issued a press release entitled `Keating wins but Australia loses'. I will quote three paragraphs from that press release:

PARA.TAB: The Native Title Bill passed through the Senate on Tuesday night after a guillotine was imposed on the debate and the Greens and Democrats voted to support the Bill. It passed through the House of Representatives yesterday morning.

"While Labor, the Democrats and Greens are patting each other on the back over Christmas drinks, Australia has been lumbered with a piece of law which is divisive and against our economic interests and prospects for increasing employment," Mr Wakelin said.
It is acknowledged that this legislation goes much further than the High Court decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I now look at a headline of recent weeks: `Mabo process seriously flawed' says National Farmers leader—and, remember, Rick Farley was very much a part of those negotiations back many months ago now.

PARA.TAB: I raise this issue tonight not with joy but with sadness, because I think our nation has a tendency to be carried away with the issues of the moment. I had discussions today with those people in the country who are probably best qualified to understand the native title issue because I was interested to try to catch up on where native title was at.

Almost two years down the track, we find that we have a piece of legislation which is seriously flawed with a no-win situation for all parties. The courts are stymied, the legislators are not able to proceed with the impending election—particularly in the federal sense—and the pastoralists live in fear, particularly those who are under claim. Let us just think about how many native title claims have been successful. On mainland Australia, not one. After all the enthusiasm that was shown in December 1993—in the International Year for the World's Indigenous People—it is sad for me to report to the parliament that we have not progressed very far at all.

In my concluding statements, I wish to comment on an article written by Christine Wallace in this week's Australian Financial Review which had the headline `The job of putting bias aside'. She talked about republicanism, and that is fine. We live in a democracy, so discussions can be held on any subject, provided it is not harmful to others.

In the emotional time when the Native Title Bill was passed, I will never forget the journalists in the Senate press gallery cheering what they saw as a landmark decision. The sad part is that, 18 months to two years down the track, not one native title claim has been finalised. All we have at the moment is a blockage of cases which may take at least 20 years to finalise if we leave things as they are.

The main point is that I want the media of Australia to remember—particularly in light of the Christine Wallace article in this week's Financial Review—that they have a responsibility to put both sides of the case. There are some people in regional Australia who can be affected by these stories. Whilst we are currently an urban dominant society, we need to take those people into account. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am looking forward to the year 2000. What I am hoping the year 2000 will bring to Australia is not so much the Sydney Olympics—which I am sure will provide a lot of good to some areas in Australia, particularly my electorate and yours, Mr Speaker, although it will be at a large cost—or the republic, which I am sure the Australian people will embrace because, unlike some people in this place, most Australians are forward looking, independent, aware of their own nature and confident in their own ability, but the next century as, hopefully, a peace century.

PARA.TAB: What has prompted me to make these comments tonight is not Bosnia-Herzegovina, not Chechnya and not many of the other trouble spots in Africa or around the globe but what the French are doing in Mururoa. It is quite obvious that the French nuclear tests must stop.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear that someone in the opposition voices approval of that. Mr Speaker, may I take the argument a little further. It is quite right for Australians to be indignant at the arrogance of these Europeans who are creating and helping to create weapons of mass destruction in our quarter. It is quite right for Australians to be totally incensed by the arrogance of these people. Why? It is not necessarily because they are bombs but because the material that is used creates a thing called radiation. Radiation is vital to life. We know that is to do with the sun, et cetera. We also know, and having been in a family that has suffered at the hands of melanomas, that radiation can also be a major killer.

PARA.TAB: I ask Australians, particularly those on the other side, to reflect on the atomic industry in Australia. I ask them to search through their minds to see whether they are happy with the way the Australian atomic industry works—or whether they are even aware of the atomic industry in this country.

I am calling upon the government to ban electric generation by nuclear power plants. There are none in Australia at the moment, but I am asking the government to take that pro-active stance and ban it. The last time that this suggestion was put up was in 1969. It was dropped by a bloke named Billy McMahon, who saw the economics of it and said, `Jervis Bay'—which happens to be in my seat—`is not going to get a nuclear power plant.' We now have all the footings and foundations there, and I understand it is the most expensive car park in the whole of Australia.

I would like electric generation to be banned because of its connection with radiation. Unless I am wrong—and my years as the deputy convener of the Australian nuclear-free zone secretariat; the deputy convenor of the Pan-Pacific nuclear-free zone secretariat, which was an international body; and an Australian delegate to the sixth international nuclear-free zone secretariat—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should go to Paris.

—I should go to Paris. I will be going to Mururoa with a bit of luck. Because of that experience, I know that the real problem is radiation. The real problem is that the by-products of this industry are so toxic that nobody yet knows how to use them. That problem is analogous with my defecating in a small backyard and having no means of getting rid of it. Ultimately, I am going to stand in it. Ultimately, it is going to affect my health. Ultimately, it is going to cause me severe problems.

PARA.TAB: In this country, we cannot afford to do that to our own territory. We do not have a national repository or an agreement for one. Are honourable members aware of the use of X-rays in airports and this parliament? Are honourable members aware of the amount of nuclear material which generates nuclear waste—in terms of X-ray images, the steel works at BHP and looking at materials to make sure they are completely and structurally solid? Vast amounts of waste are being generated. I would like the opposition to give us a bit of support on this issue, considering the 25 years of work that I have put in towards making sure that the industry is accounted for. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Gladstone is a great city which has been able to forge that elusive balance between industry and environment and between progress and lifestyle. It is the Central Queensland powerhouse of manufacturing at the northern end of my Hinkler electorate.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday marked yet another important milestone for the Gladstone region, because construction of a third potline for the aluminium manufacturer Boyne Smelters Ltd officially commenced. The third potline expansion—costing $1 billion—will almost double the production capacity of the smelter from 260,000 tonnes per year to 480,000 tonnes per year by April 1998. When completed Boyne Smelters, which is 50 per cent owned and managed by Comalco on behalf of its other joint venture partners, will be one of the three largest aluminium smelters in the Western world.

Yesterday represented a major achievement for the company, which has had to overcome a number of hurdles in recent years, including a drawn-out sale agreement with the Queensland government over the purchase of the Gladstone power station; uncertainty over bauxite supplies with the lodgment of native title claims over parts of the Weipa mineral reserves; low world aluminium prices; and an uncertain dollar. Despite these hurdles—and no doubt there are more to come—the board, management and staff have held their resolve and commitment to push ahead with the smelter and its expansion, and they were the real winners yesterday.

The economic impact of a development like Boyne Smelters is very significant to the local, state and national economies. The smelter expansion will add $632 million to the region's economy and $1,095 million to the national economy, as well as $250 million in much needed additional export revenue, given the present parlous state of our overseas payments. Interestingly, Boyne Smelters economic impact was revealed in 1993, before the current expansion. At that time it had paid out over $34 million in wages and salaries, purchased $165 million worth of goods and services from the Gladstone community, spent an additional $56 million with Queensland business and spent a further $154 million with businesses in the remainder of Australia.

Boyne Smelters is also an important value adder using both electricity generated from Central Queensland, coal from the Dawson and Callide valleys and alumina refined in Gladstone from Weipa bauxite. Refining increases the value of a tonne of bauxite from $20 per tonne to around $200 per tonne while smelting of alumina to aluminium increases the value from $200 per tonne to around $1,600 per tonne—in other words, about 80 times the original value.

Boyne Smelters currently employs 890 people on a continuous shift basis. That number will grow by a further 700 workers during the two-year construction phase and, on completion, the permanent work force will grow by a further 350 to a total work force of 1,240.

The potline expansion will bring further impetus to the emerging community of Boyne-Tannum to the south of Gladstone and highlights the need for additional government and community services in that area as it continues to grow. Paramount amongst these is the urgent need for a high school.

Finally, projects like this do not just occur. They represent company and community commitment. May I extend my congratulations to Leon Davis of CRA, chairman of the company; Terry Palmer, chief executive of Comalco; and the general manager of Boyne Smelters, Brian Bassett, on whose shoulders the heavy project falls. Tribute should also be paid to the former Mayor of Gladstone, the late Col Brown; to the present mayor, Peter Corones, who, in his previous role of Manager of Gladstone Area Promotion Inc., fostered the project; and also to Calliope mayor, Liz Cunningham, in whose shire this extraordinary enterprise has developed.

May I also pay tribute to Trudi Habner who, as the public affairs manager, has forged quality communication links between various tiers of government and the company. This latest expansion will do much to further boost business confidence in the region and open up employment opportunities for local people, especially in a region where nearly 40 per cent of teenagers seeking a job cannot get one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you, Mr Speaker, I came into this House from local government. I am sad to report to this House that local government in Victoria today is no longer democratic. That local government in Victoria needed reforming is not in dispute. Indeed, the previous Labor government attempted serious changes to local government in Victoria but were defeated, strangely enough, by the Liberal and National parties who were then in opposition.

PARA.TAB: As the usual hypocritical group of people they are, once again in government they immediately amalgamated local government, although unlike the labour movement their amalgamation process was political. They appointed Leonie Bourke, a failed candidate for the Liberal Party in a state seat, as the local government commissioner. Without consultation with any community, they then set about the process of not changing and reforming local government but destroying local government.

Yes, new boundaries have been established. But the boundaries have been established not by the process of consultation, not by the process of talking to the people who ultimately own local government—the ratepayers and the citizens of the areas—but behind closed doors. We have a peculiar situation in Victoria with the new shire of Nillimbic—which is adjacent to the municipality I served in as a councillor and shire president—having a rate base now of only $18.5 million. It is a joke. It fails all of the criteria which were established and which recognise the need for local governments.

The boundaries that are now being established are political. Very strangely, they follow the boundaries that many state Liberal Party members wanted. The shire of Strathbogie in my electorate is known locally as the McNamara shire. It follows exactly what the Deputy Premier of Victoria wanted. It has a rate base which is so low that anyone who knows local government knows that, very shortly, it will need further change to order to make it a viable economic unit.

Having established that the process itself was purely political, surprise, surprise, we then have people called commissioners appointed to the new bodies. And, surprise, surprise, the bulk of them are members of the Liberal Party. The chief commissioner gets paid $90,000 a year; the two deputy commissioners get paid $60,000 a year. Surprise, surprise, they get provided with a brand new car, mobile phone and embossed cards.

It was said that the reason for appointing commissioners was to assist in the transition of the amalgamation process. But now we are told that we will not have local government elections until 1997. Indeed, many commissioners in Victoria are now arguing that, rather than have elections, commissioners should become permanent and we should not have elected local government.

This is a Liberal Party democracy. This is what we expect from the hypocrites on the other side when they talk about democracy. When you come to a state like Victoria and see how they practise it, you know there is one thing they are frightened of—and that is people. The Liberal Party is desperately frightened of ordinary people, frightened of what people think and frightened to have people run their own affairs. The Liberal Party talks about choice. It says that is what it stands for—that all individuals have choice—but it practises the opposite. In Victoria it is demonstrable, it is alarming and it is disastrous.

In Nillimbic, for example, local community groups who set up watchdog bodies are refused total access to the commissioners. We are told that the commissioners are going to cut 20 per cent off the rates. So we are all going to get cheap rates. In the shire of Mitcham, what have they done? Guess who got the sack? Outdoor staff. Not the people behind the desks. No, they still sit there. They inherited five executive officers and they still have five executive officers. Who went? The outdoor staff, the lower paid, the people who have no defences in rural areas where unemployment is already high and severe.

Even worse than that, the commissioners then go and change the by-laws. These are people who do not live in the municipalities. They are from outside the municipalities. They are people who take their directions not from the people who pay their wages but from Mr Hallam and the state government. This is Liberal Party democracy. When people complain and say, `We want to be heard, we live here, this is our council,' they are denied access to the commissioners. Local government in Victoria is now a joke. People forget that in Boston in the United States a war was fought about taxation without representation—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have I would like to present to the House the comments of this year's winner of the Qantas-Cowan essay competition. Colleagues will remember that, for the last two years, I have brought to Canberra the winner of an essay writing competition for secondary school students, who were invited to write a 2,000-word essay on a set topic. This year's topic was: `Australia's future as a prosperous multicultural society depends on the development of a new national ethos.'

PARA.TAB: I would like to congratulate Quenton Peake of Woodvale, a year 12 student from Kingsway Christian College, on his winning entry. He spent last week here with me as part of his prize. This year's essay topic is particularly relevant in this period where the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the government have announced their preferred republic model for Australia. The Prime Minister might be interested in what a young person has to say about Australian society. Quenton starts his analysis of Australian society by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Reference to traditional Australia and the distinguishing spirit which embodied the population conjures images of survivors, people who would continue struggling against the elements. National pride resides with explorers, pioneers and those who fought for Australia's independence, providing the romantic yet tragic picture of those at Gallipoli who were willing to die for their mates. On these qualities has Australia been built and to the courage and personality of previous populations we owe our modern lifestyle as we know it. Success and prosperity has been achieved through not simply the battlers, but their unifying distinctive disposition which forces future generations to acknowledge the presence of, and benefits of emulating such traits.
He continues:

In the light of a changing society, resulting alterations to ethics and standards, and new international directions, one significant aspect of Australia's population is multiculturalism and the continuing expansion of this trend. This raises intriguing issues such as whether the traditional Australian ethos still exists and functions in a modern urban, multicultural society, whether the state of our society dictates the need for a reviewed and updated ethos or whether the individual successfully contributes to the nation's prosperity without the need for a linking characteristic between races, religions and cultures.

That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be said that debate is better the second time around. This reminds me of the song `Love is wonderful the second time around'. The genesis of this report, Time for review, of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure goes back to the report titled About time: Bills, questions and working hours, which was presented to the House on 28 October 1993. As a result of this report, there were fundamental changes made in the way the House of Representatives operates. Those changes were contentious at the time they were made, and to many members of the House those changes are still contentious.

PARA.TAB: The main argument usually centres around the issue of question time and the way question time is conducted. Opposition members generally say that they do not get a fair go from the government. The government says that the opposition gets the sort of go it deserves, given its behaviour in the House—that if time is wasted in the House, the opposition will not get the questions that it is entitled to under the standing orders.

When we look at the changes which have occurred in the House since we moved here in 1988, people such as me observe that debate has undoubtedly changed. The chamber is different. Even last night in the House, questions were being raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) regarding the difficulty faced by all members in being heard, due to the acoustic systems and the sheer size of the chamber itself. Certainly, I miss the old chamber in the old house. It was a much better debating chamber. We were closer to our adversaries in political debate and the interchange between members in the course of debate was more fluid and more witty. The house itself operated without the need for artificial acoustic or artificial sound producing devices. It was truly a debating chamber.

I suspect that many of these changes that we are now talking about which have occurred since 1988 are very largely a result of the changed nature of the chamber, and the difficulty that people have in expressing their political views in the course of debate. I do not envy Mr Speaker or you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when you take the chair in the House—or indeed any person who takes the chair there. In my observation of the changes I have seen, it is increasingly difficult to maintain any degree of control in the main chamber of the House of Representatives. Again, that is very largely the nature of the chamber itself, the difficulty of hearing and, quite often, the background noise levels that are operating there whilst debate is being conducted.
It is also fair to say that, in politics today, political parties use the forms of the House to either embarrass or bring into disorder government functions and operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never.

—The right honourable member for New England smiles at me gently and says, `Get away with you,' or words to that effect. It is a truism. There is no better practitioner of the art of politics than the member for New England. I say to him, as I have said to him privately, that I often wonder why he sits on the back bench when there is no more skilled parliamentary performer, in terms of procedure and disruption, in this House. It may be that from the government's viewpoint it is wise to ensure that he stays on the back bench and does not lend his unarguable experience and talent to the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Question time is undoubtedly the time that most procedural reports focus on. That is where most anger and attention is drawn. Question time is a procedure which is evolving. It is a procedure which, from the early days of the Westminster system, was an evolving thing. In the early days of the English parliament there was no formalised question time at all. It was a practice which evolved over many years. In the House of Representatives in Australia, question time came about by the Standing Orders Committee of the House, in 1902, 1903 and 1905, establishing the framework in which question time operated.

The government's view is that the present system gives a further operational time frame and further examination. I can understand the view of an opposition, hungry and anxious to bring the government to account in a critical sense in the House of Representatives but being frustrated by the present system, whereby many members of the government, particularly the executive, are not present in the House during question time. I can imagine myself on the other side having a particular need to attack a member of the government but being frustrated by the fact that that member is not there. However, it is also true to say that honourable members have an entitlement to question ministers in a very short space of time the following day.

I have listened with interest to many arguments put by members of the opposition that the Prime Minister should be in the House on a daily basis. It has often puzzled me why the opposition would want that. In my experience, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is one of the great weapons of the government. I am quite sure that, if the Prime Minister were in the House on a daily basis, the opposition would get to a stage of not wanting to ask any questions because of the capacity that the Prime Minister has to devastate the opposition so readily and so capably and ably in the course of question time. I would have thought that the opposition would be much happier to have the Prime Minister in on only two days a week, when he does not do so much damage to the opposition in a critical sense, rather than insisting on the Prime Minister coming in on a daily basis. That is a personal perspective, of course.

No doubt honourable members on the other side would say that, if the Prime Minister were in on a daily basis, their debating skills would be such that they would devastate the Prime Minister and, particularly, embarrass the government. I have been watching in this place for a long while and I have not seen it happen yet. I have severe doubts whether there is anyone in this House who has the capacity during question time to cause embarrassment to the government by attacking the Prime Minister.

There is a point I want to make about question time which is my personal view. As a politician I get annoyed at the fact that people in the general community have a rather dim view of me as a person of my calling and of my activities as an elected representative of the Australian parliament. I have found, in the relatively short space of time I have been a member of this House, that that view is growing. It does annoy me: I know that it is not true, certainly from my own perspective, and when I look at other members of this House that I know, I know that they are dedicated people. They have particular views which I may disagree with but which nevertheless they hold dearly. They are here because of those views and they are here to represent their particular viewpoint and their constituents in this parliament.

My annoyance on that is compounded when I watch the conduct of the House during question time. All of us are responsible for the way we are viewed by the general community. Members of the general community, as we generally know, view the proceedings of this place generally only at question time. They have a very poor understanding of the role of parliamentarians in committees and debate in general times. The media—television, particularly—focus in on that very short part of the day's activities called question time, when the focus is on personal debate. That is all they see. I think sometimes that honourable members on both sides could remember the focus of television, particularly, on the behaviour of honourable members during question time.

I often smile to myself during question time when points of order are raised referring to standing order 145, on relevance. If there was ever a useless point of order, or a point of order which honourable members should understand is not applicable during question time, that is one. Yet simply by raising standing order 145 as a point of order during question time they bring the House into disrepute. They create the disturbance which television shows so adequately and which brings all honourable members into disrepute. I think sometimes that there really should be an introduction course for honourable members in this place so they understand clearly what 145 means and what points of order relevant to 145 really mean. They would then not bring the House into so much disrepute by asking irrelevant points of order, claiming that 145 is applicable.

My main concern is the fact that members of parliament are seen by the general public as not being serious and as being irrelevant. The House is not seen as being a serious chamber and we are all largely responsible for the way in which the public sees us.

I do not believe that the changes to question time have been deleterious to the opposition. I have indicated that, if I were a member of the opposition, the last person I would want in the House every day is the Prime Minister.
Mr Nehl interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the member who is interjecting were on the front bench and could use his undoubted forensic skills, what he says might be applicable. However, with the current front bench of the opposition, it is very hard to get one or two of them to ask a reasonable question which could cause any damage to the government, so I am not too sure about that.

PARA.TAB: I can understand why members who have been in the parliament for a long while and who make a tradition of question time express strong views about question time. What will the opposition do if it ever gets government in this country? Will the members of the opposition change the standing orders in that case? If the executive were composed of opposition members and it had to contend with the current pressures of government—it is becoming much harder every year—would the opposition want its ministers to spend as much time in the House of Representatives as was required under the old rules? Would the opposition want to change the current standing orders or are most of the attacks by the opposition purely political in order to suggest that the government is frightened of having its ministers in the House during question time? It would be interesting to know if the opposition has a policy as to what it would do were it the government.

In answer to the member who interjected, the opposition often says such things, but, of course, members on both sides of the House know that what is said in opposition for political purposes and what is done in government are historically different things.

TALK.START.PARA: —L-a-w. Tell us about that.

—L-a-w, we are told. I am very cautious about whether, if the opposition were in government, it would change the current standing orders and, in doing so, bring back question time in its original form.
—My very word we will!

—Are you saying `my very word' again? We have got two going for this one; we will go for three if we are lucky. As I have already said, I have my doubts that the opposition would change the current standing orders. All in all, I welcome both reports of the Procedure Committee, including, of course, the specific report on question time in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I urge members to ensure that they understand the current forms of the House and the current standing orders, and I urge members not to waste the time of the House with spurious and unnecessary points of order during question time. I ask members who do so not to use the procedures for misrepresentation in order to debate. Some members of the House forget that they are responsible for bringing the House into disrepute when they breach current standing orders and yet happily accuse other members of abusing standing orders. One of the most abused procedures of the House is the procedure whereby members can claim to have been misrepresented. Members on this side know that the Leader of the Opposition constantly uses this procedure as a debating tool in the parliament. The Leader of the Opposition knows that he is in breach of the standing orders when he does so. I urge members to stand down when Mr Speaker suggests that they do so, instead of ignoring the chair.

Behaviour in the House is in the control of members. No matter what we do with the reports of the Procedure Committee and no matter how we change standing orders, ultimately members on both sides will be judged as people and as politicians by the way they perform irrespective of what standing orders say. Members can debate and members can change standing orders so that every minister comes into the House, but if, during question time, people continue to behave the way they are, the public will judge members accordingly.

I do not believe any changes to the standing orders are necessary because the current system has proved to be successful and this chamber has proved to be successful. This chamber provides another forum for members of the House to spend time debating non-contentious issues. I am sure that my good friend the honourable member for New England will say that this is a contentious issue rather than a non-contentious issue. Nevertheless, the procedures are operating and the reports of the Procedure Committee simply verify the view of the government that the current system is successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that we have a debate on standing orders, and I commend the Procedure Committee for the successive papers it has produced. It does not mean that all of us necessarily agree with everything in the papers, but it is true that a leader of the House tends to concentrate far more on the processing and procedures related to the passage of government legislation than on giving adequate opportunity to members to debate legislation and those matters which are a priority to them. The Procedure Committee has certainly increased the opportunity for consideration of the degree to which standing orders facilitate members' performance, and that is important. Members having an input into the way in which the parliament is run is for the good.

PARA.TAB: However, it is appropriate that we have a discussion from time to time about each change as it is made. I for one am not as committed as the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) to the efficacy of this place. I am afraid I tend to be a bit of a traditionalist. I think it is very sad that the parliament has been eroded. It is not erosion in relation to the executive that I am talking about; it is erosion of a forum where genuine debate can be facilitated.

I know that a couple of these recommendations are intended to address some of the areas to which attention needs to be paid. For example, I believe ministers must be there to deliver their second reading speech; I believe ministers must be there to sum up; I believe ministers should be there to present amendments; and I think they have to treat the parliamentary debate as an extension of their own responsibilities and not one to be delegated just to a parliamentary secretary. Whatever the advantages of parliamentary secretaries, the minister who is responsible for legislation should at least give courtesy to those who have done some work on particular legislation and are concerned about the effect of legislation, and by being there help to encourage better debate on the text of that legislation.

We have had far too many occasions when there have been necessary changes to legislation because of inadequate debate. It is important to divorce the political process from the legislative process—they inevitably become intertwined—but it is important that whatever legislation is passed by parliament is effective, accurate and takes into account the impact it will have on the Australian electorate and on the Australian people at large—those who are not electors. Unless we do that properly, it is we who fail in our job. Quite often, because the minister is not there and does not hear the debate, the debate is less than effective. It is necessary that we address that, and some of the modifications suggested in this legislation, particularly regarding the attendance of ministers, need to be addressed by ministers themselves. I would be quite happy for changes to our standing orders to be addressed in that respect.

I come to another concern: the more changes that are made to standing orders, the more difficult it becomes to understand them. As Leader of the House, I found it more appropriate to introduce what we call sessional orders as distinct from standing orders. The advantage of those is not to in any way lessen their impact on the parliament or the way in which they are applied but sessional orders can apply until a stage is reached when it is felt that they are exactly correct, at which point they can be introduced into standing orders. By changing the standing orders all the time, it is a bit like the tax act: one has to go through so many changes to try and work out what the original form was that one is not sure. In some instances, we do better to test our changes, as indeed this report suggests we are now doing, and have sessional orders which modify the operation; and then when accepted as the desirable form they can become part of the standing orders.

The standing orders should be ongoing. I notice that there are a few recommendations in this report and we have had a few modifications in the past which in part are now being revised. If they had been sessional orders we would not have got to the position of having to look upon the amendments on the amendments on the amendments; we would have a sessional order which is seen as temporary until it is written into legislation. I make that suggestion for this discussion paper, which I commend the Procedure Committee on being about to produce.

The second thing that worries me is the status of this Main Committee. I said that I am a complete devotee of the parliament and I want to try to get better debate there, but I will come back to the parliament in a moment. I am glad to see the committee has before it the question of whether attendance here is attendance at the parliament. I found it in this session quite incredible that we were debating the appropriations bill in a parliamentary Main Committee which does not entitle members to attendance—forgetting the allowance bit of it—and members are not registered as attending parliament if they attend here. That meant that we were discussing the very substance of the difference between the House of Representatives and the Senate in a committee which is not the parliament. I find that just unacceptable.

If we are going to discuss the appropriation bills in the Main Committee, it means we must be attending parliament, because it is only in the House of Representatives that we can deal with financial matters. If it is only in the parliament that we can deal with financial matters, how the devil can they be discussed here, if we are not part of the parliament and if we are not attending parliament when we attend here? That is a mere anomaly, but it is one that needs to be identified, addressed and understood.

As far as the procedures in the Main Committee are concerned, they do give members a greater opportunity to talk, and that is good. Demonstrably, the audience is a little more intimate, and that is one of the advantages of the Main Committee. It is for that reason that—come the revolution and the change of government, which I anticipate will occur fairly soon—there are a few things that we need to seriously address. Putting politics aside, I would hope that the Procedure Committee might consider identifying those matters, if only to give them a trial. I am prepared to accept that it might only be on a sessional basis.

The first thing that I would like to do is draw the two sides of the parliament together. I know that the layout of the parliament was decided, for all sorts of reasons such as that we wanted to have more people, but I would like to see the two sides drawn closer together. We are closer together here. We talk because we can see each other. It was apropos of that point that I spoke about the acoustics of the main chamber yesterday. I find it quite ridiculous that you cannot hear what is going on there half the time. The acoustics are brilliant when there is nobody in the room, but fill it with a group of people and you cannot hear anything! Yet it is when the parliament is full, and when everybody is seated and there are a few speakers having an interchange, that we really need to know what is going on; but it is then that we cannot. I want to have people closer together—

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Crawford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mary, we will always submit to you and listen to you. But it is true that we do need to have the two sides of the parliament closer together and we need to promote the idea of being able to debate. To do that, we want to make it more intimate. I know I have views which have not been to date accepted by Mr Speaker—I suspect by the Clerks rather than by Mr Speaker—regarding allowing people to sit on the perimeter of the chamber. I think it is quite ridiculous that we do not allow special guests to sit at the back and—
—We used to!

—Of course we did; and nobody interfered with us or in any way created any sort of a security scare. In fact, the only security scare we had was when somebody jumped over the balcony; and they can still jump over the balcony! I persist in the thought that we ought to have a Speaker's gallery and the Deputy Speaker or the Speaker would be able to give approval for people to sit there. I would like to see a section reserved for members of the other place and another section reserved for special invited guests who would be given special tickets.

PARA.TAB: It is quite inappropriate, for example, for the Prime Minister's wife to have to sit up in the gallery—or, in this modern age, the Prime Minister's spouse. If we had the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) as our Prime Minister and if her spouse—were she married—wished to sit on the floor of the chamber, it would be very appropriate for that person to be able to do so. By bringing the parliament closer together and improving the actual debating forum, we would allow greater facility with that sort of venue. We have room to do it, and I would like to see a trial layout—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the diplomatic corps.

—Yes; and the diplomatic corps. There are a number of particular people. We are having visitors more frequently from overseas, and I do not believe it appropriate that they be stuck up in a gallery where one has to just about crick one's neck to know whether they are there. If we cannot see them, they are out of sight and out of mind, which is not really what we want. We have got to bring them into our parliamentary process.

PARA.TAB: There is another very real diplomatic reason that this is desirable: far too few of them have a democracy such as ours. If we bring them onto the floor of our parliament, they might well understand that, for all that we have adversarial dialogue from time to time, it is a process which enables the proper expression of individual points of view, irrespective of what those views might be, and that it is that which is really the hallmark of our democracy. I am getting diverted, as I wanted to say a few things about a couple of other items in the report, but I do recommend that, in the discussion paper, some time be spent on looking at a trial of a different way to make parliament a little more workable.

I have a couple of observations about these changes to standing orders, and I have said that I think they ought to be sessional. I have made a couple of comments on occasions about the importance of the minister's second reading speech being available when the bill itself is presented. It is more and more important today because the High Court has decided that the minister's second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum should be taken into account when determining the application of law. Therefore, we need to have the minister's second reading speech available to determine the degree and the character of the legislation and the nuances behind it. I think that recommendation 3.3 certainly needs to be adopted.

This issue raises with me the question of whether the first reading procedure is necessary. I would be more inclined to adopt a procedure which said that at the time the first reading is made the first reading speech should be what is now said to be the minister's second reading speech. We have that formality now but there is no need for that first reading, if we get rid of the reason to have it. We need a third reading because that is dealing with the bill as a whole. We need at least two readings but, in my view, we could happily get away with a first reading that presented the minister's second reading speech as we now know it and then a second reading which would be the bill being dealt with as a whole. In that way, the second reading would become the first reading and the third reading would become the second reading. I think that would be a more sensible process.

Of course, we would still deal with it in committee. I am not committed to the idea of the Speaker still sitting up on the top chair for the committee process. I confess to preferring the greater intimacy of having the Speaker speak from the floor. Members addressing a public meeting do not want to sit up the front in a daze: they want to get down amongst the people and get close to them. They need to get down amongst the people so that everyone feels they are part of it. That is how the committee process should be and I would like to see more of that.
There are a dozen things here that I will briefly talk on. Recommendation 3.4.6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is recommended that departments take steps to improve the usefulness of explanatory memoranda . . .
We have to remember that the explanatory memorandum needs to be the legislation in simple language, but usefulness is not as important as legality.

PARA.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 10.32 a.m. to 10.44 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see Peter Gibson in his new position of high authority. We welcome him and are sure that he will contribute significantly to the standard of advice that we receive from those who are clerks in this place.

PARA.TAB: In concluding, I just wanted to say a couple of brief things. Paragraph 9.3.6 on page 35 says that question time should commence at 2.30. I think that should be accepted by the government. I think it is mad having it at 3 o'clock; it is too late in the afternoon.
Paragraph 9.2.8 on page 33 says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is recommended that no change be made to the sitting hours of the House.

I think that not having meals is stupid. Part of the purpose of changing the sitting hours was to try to allow people to have some reasonable time at night. I regularly go through without lunch and without dinner. At times, I get invitations to three or four of each but that is not the point. We badly need to have time within which we can have committee meetings without interruption, particularly because the standing orders of the Senate prevent all the joint committees meeting while the other house is sitting. If we had at least an hour at dinner and an hour at lunch, for many, it would mean people could get some exercise. There are variants we can introduce to obtain that. I certainly do not accept that our present sitting hours are preferable. I would like to see formalised breaks so that people can either eat if they wish or conduct some of the other functions which are an essential part of parliamentary life.

PARA.TAB: In the 55 seconds that I have left, I want to say something about questions. I do not agree with the idea of having ministers rostered on. I think it is better for them all to be there. The statistics mean absolutely nothing. The way questions run depends on the issues. To my mind, structured questions from either side are far worse than rostered ministers. I would prefer to see at least half the questions on each occasion, certainly, from the opposition, without restraint and without discipline. I think it is far better for members to have an opportunity to ask questions on matters that are of moment to them. I have real doubts about the question time procedure as it is at the moment.

I would have liked an opportunity to say more on this matter. In this report, I think question time remains very much open to review. I do not agree with it as it is running now. I commend the analysis in paragraph 6.1.2 on page 20, which does, in fact, set down many of the issues. I commend the committee and look forward to reading the general review which I gather is to be produced some time in the next parliament. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to be able to talk to the Time for review report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. It is also an honour to be able to follow the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) on a discussion of procedure within the House of Representatives and its associated committees. If the right honourable member for New England rises on a point of order when I am in the chair as a presiding officer, I take note and listen intently because he is usually on to something, whereas I might be a little dismissive of other people, whilst, of course, giving them due consideration. I do indicate to the honourable member that, from both sides of the chamber, his understanding of the workings of this place are well valued.

PARA.TAB: In the last couple of minutes, something else attracted me. It was the first thing I had written in my sketchy notes in preparation for this speech on the review of the sitting times of the House. It struck me that, in creating what are thought to be more civilised times of sitting, the notion not to have any meal breaks seems a little silly. I say that not only in respect of members but also in respect of all those people who work in support of our operations. It is a very difficult juggling task to roster people through meal breaks and I cannot understand why there is no break at least for lunch or dinner, in recognition of the efforts of the support people, just for the sake of sitting through and finishing at 9 o'clock or so.

I think the new hours have worked well because they have created those early nights. But, whilst I am a great supporter of this chamber and whilst I think it is of great value to the workings of the parliament, it has added to our frenetic pace. This was illustrated this morning when there was a division in the main chamber. The proceedings of the Main Committee were suspended while we all went to the division and then we all traipsed back here. Members are often trying to keep an eye on what is happening in the main chamber because they have an interest in both places, and that is difficult. One of the things that characterises this place for me is the breathless arrival of members as they scurry from their involvement downstairs to participate upstairs in the Main Committee. The frenetic pace has resulted in dual responsibilities for a lot of people—not only for members but also for clerks, attendants, Hansard and a whole host of other people.

In particular, I want to thank two people: the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who is here in the chamber, and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). They have to take a dual role within their party because of its size: not only are they members of the Speaker's panel but also they are National Party whips for the coalition. They undertake their role in this place with great diligence. I appreciate that they have quite an immense juggling act to ensure that their time is spread over both those roles. I think it should be placed on record that there are people who appreciate their efforts and their cooperation.

Much has been said in the report about the way in which legislation is dealt with. Some of those matters are worthy of discussion and comment. It is, on balance, difficult to know whether or not the second reading speech should be made at the time of presentation of the bill. I agree with the conclusion reached by the committee that we should go back to the old system. It is helpful in preparation for the debate for members to know what the minister or parliamentary secretary who has carriage of the legislation has said in support of that legislation.

I understand that there would be some difficulties and that it would require some changes in standing orders to get that legislation into the Main Committee. That might also lead to coalition spokespeople in portfolio areas querying whether they should have the same opportunity to give their second reading speech in the same chamber as the minister or parliamentary secretary. They are issues that the committee has talked through. They are issues that, quite appropriately, are matters for further discussion.

The report also highlights in tabular form how often the appropriate minister or the appropriate parliamentary secretary takes carriage of his or her legislation. This is an important aspect which is worthy of critical analysis by both sides—and it has attracted comments from both sides of the chamber. On behalf of executive government, those who have direct responsibility for legislation should take a particular interest in that legislation.

Not only should they present the second reading speech, but they should also have carriage of the wrapping up of the debate, especially consideration in detail. They should take carriage of and responsibility for amendments that are made at that stage. That is a basic responsibility that those who act on behalf of the executive should undertake. I have no problem with whether it is the senior minister, junior minister or parliamentary secretary, as long as it is a person who has responsibility within the portfolio area of the legislation which is being presented.

There are many individual ministers and parliamentary secretaries who take those duties very seriously and who, without fail, try to do the right thing by the House of Representatives. However, it was quite correct for the committee to highlight that. I hope the executive government can see fit to make the appropriate arrangements to ensure that, wherever possible, the responsible person is in either the Main Committee or the main chamber to take carriage of the legislation. Having said that, members acknowledge that those people have other responsibilities. However, like ordinary backbench members and people who have other positions within the House, they need to juggle their time to ensure that those responsibilities are covered.

The committee also recommended that ways should be investigated to encourage visitors to parliament to observe the proceedings of the Main Committee. That is something that has troubled me from time to time. I was unsure what information was being provided to visitors to Parliament House about the operations of the Main Committee. I am told that the Main Committee is mentioned in the pamphlet on the House of Representatives.

There is some signage which indicates where the Main Committee is being held. From time to time, people find themselves observing what is going on here. Perhaps we should consider producing a brochure, pamphlet or handout that more fully explains how this chamber operates, and explains the difference between it and the main chamber. That would include such things as how members are allocated positions in the main chamber, whereas members in the Main Committee are able to speak from whatever position they like. I think that those differences need to be noted.

On the whole I think, as other contributors to this debate have indicated, this Main Committee has been an outstanding success. It has opened up the amount of time that has been made available to members to debate important issues. It is not only legislation which after agreement between the coalition and the government is called non-controversial which comes up here for debate. I stress again that to say the legislation is non-controversial is not to say that the debate cannot be controversial; it is just the nature of the legislation that gives the definition. The loose definition means that the legislation should not be required to come to a vote; that is the important matter.

The overwhelming advantage that this Main Committee has given is our ability to speak to reports like the one that is before the Committee at the moment. It must be bordering on a dozen members who have been able to come up here and make quite full contributions in response to this well crafted report. Later today we will have the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on Lake Pedder debated more fully than would have been possible for us if we had relied upon the main chamber. That has been the great advantage of having this additional debating time.

There have been comments about the lack of atmosphere in this room. That is something that will slowly but surely develop. Let me say, on behalf of the presiding officers and the clerks, that we are always open to suggestions about what we can do to improve the environs of this room. Comment has been made throughout this debate that there is a different style of debate coming about because of the intimacy of this place. I think that is good. That is an advantage. For those who have a knowledge of Australian rules, it is akin to the atmosphere at a game out at the AFL ground at Waverley Park, where it was thought that pushing back the spectators and giving a large space around the boundaries would be an advantage. This has been something that has been rejected by those who follow that code. They prefer to go to grounds like the MCG, where the boundaries have remained the traditional distance from the action and people can feel more involved. To a certain extent I think we have that sort of atmosphere down in the larger chamber. There have been suggestions made about how we can perhaps get around that. There has also been the debate about visitors going into the chamber, and the security implications and things like that. Perhaps we just have to revisit those continually to see what can be done.

I want to give a warning that, even though we are at a close distance, the debate must always be carried on through the chair. Because of the smaller distances between the sides of the chamber here, greater debate can be encouraged; and we should not see, as we continue to see down in the main chamber, set pieces made. Members come in, make their set speeches and trot out; and then others come in and make speeches that do not relate to what is happening around them. I think that that is a sad thing, and I think that we should do everything to encourage people to enter into debate, interchange and discussion.

A couple of months back, whilst the Speaker was away, I had duties as Acting Speaker, and I received a note of encouragement from a former speaker of the Legislative Assembly in Victoria, Ken Coghill, who indicated a wish that we could encourage members to understand the importance of addressing their remarks through the chair. I know that when you are an occupant of the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you are very strict on that. Dr Coghill believed that, if we were even more strict on that, it would take the heat out of the debate. When there is a continual `You did this, you did that' across the chamber it becomes very personalised, and through this simple step we give a bit of space.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I missed the comment of the member for Murray, but I am sure it is helpful at this stage.
—I was just saying that doing it that way filters it through.
—Yes. I think there needs to be that break, that filter; it needs to have that one step through. It takes the heat out of it and you can still have an interchange that is helpful.

PARA.TAB: On the whole, the procedure changes that were under review by this report of the committee are appropriate. I think the comments that are made about question time can be taken on board and are a helpful compromise to get over one of the concerns that the coalition has. I am a supporter of the rostering. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Langmore:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I tabled the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled The proposal to drain and restore Lake Pedder, in the House on Monday, I briefly referred to the committee's main conclusions. Today I want to speak in more detail about some of the committee's findings. Before I do, I would like to briefly comment on misleading remarks by the Tasmanian Premier and others about the cost of the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The Tasmanian Premier apparently said on Monday that the inquiry had cost about $1 million. As far as we have been able to estimate, the cost was about $60,000. It may have been that the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania spent quite a lot of money in preparing its evidence, but that is not part of the cost of the inquiry. The cost of the inquiry itself was the cost of the staff time, the travel of members, the printing of the report and the conduct of hearings, and our best estimate of that is $60,000. I think it is important to correct that misjudgment that the Tasmanian Premier made.

I want to begin my comments on the committee's findings by elaborating on our conclusion that it would be inappropriate to allocate resources to the further consideration of the proposal to restore Lake Pedder. This view was based on two basic observations: first, that further consideration would involve some costs; and, second, that there are other, more important environmental programs and goals that warrant higher priority. The likely costs which would be incurred if the proposal was implemented were a controversial and strongly contested issue. We were not able to make a definitive estimate ourselves, but came to the view that it is likely that there would be significant long-term costs if the proposal were to proceed.

Even if we look only at the option of further consideration of the proposal, it is clear that considerable planning, research, monitoring and the preparation of a thorough environmental impact assessment would be required before a commitment could be made to proceed. This work alone would be quite costly. It would not be worth allocating resources to such tasks unless there was a real likelihood that the proposal would attract the necessary level of support. But, more importantly, it would only be appropriate to allocate resources if we were sure that other projects and goals were adequately funded. This is clearly not the case at present.

We were told that there is already a backlog of important works in the World Heritage area and that funding for these and some other projects is inadequate. I am concerned that funding an environmental impact statement, for example, would make it less likely that some of the other projects required in the World Heritage areas could be funded. Some of those in favour of the Lake Pedder restoration proposal argued that the committee not be distracted by the question of priorities. But the reality for all governments is that there is a need to allocate funds to a range of competing expenditure proposals and there are never sufficient funds to adequately implement all of even the most worthwhile or urgent projects.

The possible allocation of resources to the Lake Pedder proposal would have to be considered in a broad, national context. This would go beyond the question of its relative priority in the allocation of funds to the management of the Tasmanian wilderness World Heritage area. The need to take a wider perspective is most apparent if one looks at the long-term potential for both the state and the Commonwealth governments to be committed to an expensive and open-ended program to rehabilitate the drained area or compensate for the loss of electricity.

As I mentioned, these costs were strongly disputed in the evidence and the committee was unable to make a definitive estimate of what the cost might be. Much would depend on questions that are not yet resolved. The future of Comalco at Bell Bay, for example, would be significant to the valuation of potential electricity generation. It is fair to say that many members of the committee were somewhat sceptical of the cost estimates presented by the Tasmanian government and the Hydro-Electric Commission but, by the same token, the estimates of either little cost or a positive benefit presented by those in favour of the proposal were also received with some scepticism.

It is clear that one possibility is that the cost would run to hundreds of millions of dollars. This is a significant figure if we look at some other environmental programs and goals. In 1992, this committee reported on the role of protected areas in biodiversity. We found that there was an urgent need to complete the range of representative reserves to ensure that all ecosystem types are adequately protected around the country. The committee made several recommendations that would require funding. The most significant of these was the provision by the Commonwealth of $100 million over six years to establish a tied grants program specifically for the purpose of acquiring identified areas to be included in a nationwide system of ecologically representative core protected areas.

Whilst I appreciate the recent efforts of the government in finding funds in the budget for a national biodiversity strategy, I remain disappointed that the funding is inadequate compared to the need identified by the committee. There is no doubt in my mind that a fully funded national biodiversity strategy has a much higher priority than the proposal to drain and restore Lake Pedder. I personally could not support allocating funds to the Lake Pedder proposal while the biodiversity strategy remains so seriously under-funded. Other environmental and conservation programs that one could think of involve a measure of some urgency, where there is often a need to intervene before the situation gets worse or more damage is done. The landcare and tree planting programs are particularly good examples of this.

Christine Milne, the leader of the Tasmanian Greens, explained to the committee why consideration of priorities could lead the committee to undervalue the Lake Pedder proposal but, in so doing, she referred to the need to respond to immediate issues. I find that this is one of the difficulties that arise in supporting the proposal. Mrs Milne said that in the short term she was constantly engaged in issues where destruction was imminent, and she mentioned the European carp infestation of Tasmanian lakes and dieback in the central highlands of Tasmania as examples of what she described as immediate issues. Other witnesses also listed those two high priorities.

The Lake Pedder proposal is not urgent in this sense. There is no damage being done and no need for immediate remedial intervention. It was quite clear that, after nearly 25 years of inundation, the features that are most important to the restoration proposal remain preserved under the waters of the current Lake Pedder and are likely to remain intact for some time to come. Draining the current lake would allow these features to be observed and appreciated.
