I believe that, if practical, this could be worth while because it would enhance the World Heritage values of the Tasmanian wilderness World Heritage area.

I was impressed by the evidence of Dr Kevin Kiernan, who clearly showed the importance of the unique geomorphological features associated with the original Lake Pedder. Dr Kiernan introduced the committee to the concept of geoconservation. In my mind, this reinforced the view that the decision to flood Lake Pedder was wrong and it also emphasised the importance of the area as World Heritage. From what Dr Kiernan told us, I consider that the geomorphological features associated with the original lake would be significant aspects of the world's natural heritage. We are indebted to Dr Kiernan for raising this issue and to Professor Tyler for showing that these features have not been lost.

The current Lake Pedder also has significant and important values. I said at the time of the committee's visit to the lake that is a magnificent lake, and I remain of that view. It has great scenic attraction, it is an important trout fishery and it is a beautiful place to visit. But none of these characteristics are of World Heritage significance. It appears that the current Lake Pedder was included in the World Heritage area mainly for administrative and management purposes rather than for any addition it might make to the World Heritage values of the area. I disagree with those who suggested to the committee that the loss of the current Lake Pedder would diminish the World Heritage values of the area. The argument that draining the lake would be contrary to the provisions of the World Heritage convention was wrong in law and seriously misinterpreted the convention. It was also wrong in its evaluation of World Heritage features.

I am sympathetic to those who appreciate Lake Pedder in its current form but they are wrong if they suggest that the original lake did not possess significant World Heritage values or that the World Heritage value of the current lake exceeds that of the original. However, it cannot be said that restoring Lake Pedder is necessary to protect World Heritage values, nor is there a conservation or environmental imperative for restoration.

There is one matter related to World Heritage about which I would agree with those who are opposed to draining the lake. It is not necessary, nor would it be possible, to completely restore Lake Pedder and its surrounds to their pre-flooding condition. However, we should not underestimate the capacity of nature to regenerate itself. Earlier this year, I read a very interesting autobiography by Professor Edward Wilson, who is a noted ecologist, in fact a global leader of the ecological profession. He had done experiments with tiny islands, completely removing life forms from them, and had then observed how quickly life forms, plant forms, insects, birds and so on had re-established themselves on those tiny islands. He found very rapid regeneration within a year and almost complete regeneration within a few years. That is a different situation, of course, from draining a lake and looking for recovery but it does give some indication of the capacity of nature to regenerate very quickly.

Draining and restoring Lake Pedder would attract considerable international interest. I believe that, if it proceeded smoothly and reasonably quickly, the efforts of the Tasmanian and the Australian communities would be much appreciated internationally. However, I do not believe that the world community would patiently withhold its condemnation if the rehabilitation process failed. There would be an expectation, one which the Australian community would share with the world, that we would then undertake a major restoration effort to protect the World Heritage values. That, of course, could be quite costly. The prospects for successfully rehabilitating the whole area, not just the original Lake Pedder itself, and for protecting the World Heritage values in the long term are questions that would need to be answered before the proposal could proceed.

I would now like to refer to the evidence relating to the platypus population in the current lake. I understand that at least one article in the Hobart Mercury has recently suggested that the evidence presented by Professor Forteath left the committee with no option but to oppose the proposal. This, as would be clear from our report, was not the case. It was perhaps unfortunate that Professor Forteath appeared at the public hearing in Hobart without first either making a written submission or presenting his credentials. We did not have an opportunity to consider his observation nor were we in a position to evaluate his standing as a potential expert witness before he appeared at the hearing.

Following the hearing, we sought the views of the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and we also received a submission from an acknowledged expert in platypus ecology. We became quite sceptical about Professor Forteath's evidence and do not regard him to be an expert in platypus population sampling. We note that, as he later made clear to the committee, his estimates of the Lake Pedder platypus population were based on casual field observations made while he was trout fishing.

This provided some information about the population but it did not amount to a rigorous, scientifically sound sampling methodology. However, as noted by the committee in its report, it was the only evidence available about the platypus population in the current Lake Pedder. It would have been better if Professor Forteath had explained at the public hearing that he was not an expert on platypus populations, that he had not scientifically sampled the population and that he had a particular interest in the retention of the lake. Despite these oversights, Professor Forteath's evidence was of some value because it raised a possible implication of the proposal that might otherwise have been overlooked. His concerns can be extrapolated beyond the platypus population to the possible fate of other species present in the current lake.

In relation to the Lake Pedder proposal, I am more concerned about endangered species such as the Pedder galaxias than the platypus. The general point that Professor Forteath raised is another one of the questions that would have to be carefully and thoroughly addressed if the proposal were to proceed.

The decision to flood the lake was taken against a background of ignorance and shameful disregard of the biology of the original lake. We should not allow a similar mistake to be made in any hastily arrived at decision to now drain it. The question of the populations of plants and animals in the lake highlights the need for some very serious questions to be addressed if the proposal were to proceed. It is our firm conclusion that allocating resources to answer these questions is inappropriate while there are other higher priority and more urgent matters to be dealt with.

Let me conclude by dealing with the suggestion that the committee has `squibbed out' by not supporting the restoration proposal. It would have been very easy for us to avoid the issue by recommending that further research be carried out. Instead, the committee came to a considered conclusion, based on the evidence, and we had the conviction to stand by that conclusion. I believe it is an authoritative conclusion. We have presented a report that we knew in advance would be criticised by those who would disagree with our findings, but it is a report that we believe is the most responsible and appropriate answer to the restoration proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is a bit of a risk to preface my remarks by saying that I suspect I am going to agree with just about everything that my colleagues on this particular inquiry have had to say, with the notable exception, of course, of the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth).
—He is a notable exception.
—Good, I am pleased to be one.

—I know the honourable member will have something else to say. We were almost unanimous in this report. I suppose being almost unanimous is like being slightly pregnant but 11 out of 12 is not bad. I came into this particular inquiry very much looking forward to it. I joined the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and Arts because of my particular interest in the environment, only to be embroiled within weeks of joining the committee with the so-called sports rorts affair. I had the impression then that this was going to be a thoroughly unpleasant experience. However, apart from that one aberration, it has been a most delightful and interesting committee to work on. No inquiry, or anything that we have been involved in, have I found more interesting than the inquiry into the proposal to drain and restore Lake Pedder.

PARA.TAB: I came into the inquiry with the view that the lake probably should be drained and that is a view that I had held for a long time. Many, many moons ago, when I was a much younger man, I was of the opinion—as were so many other Australians at that time—that it should not be flooded. I suppose I had kept that view in the back of my mind for all of these years, so when this inquiry was called I thought, `Good, we will be able to have a thorough, decent inquiry into this and, at the end of it, recommend that we drain the lake.'

I have attended all but one of the public hearings where we have taken evidence and what have you. I visited Tasmania twice with the committee. The committee spent an entire day at Lake Pedder. Having listened to everything that everyone had to say, and considered it long and hard, I came to the conclusion, as did the majority of the committee—11 out of 12—that it was not on, that we would have to recommend against the draining of Lake Pedder.

A couple of things were of a particular concern to me. When we viewed the lake, I, like the chairman, was most impressed by the beauty of the current Lake Pedder. I thought it was one of the most magnificent sights that I had seen in my life. No doubt the original Lake Pedder was also a magnificent sight. I was amazed at the cliffs, and at the beaches that had formed around the perimeter of the current lake. I am talking about some hundreds of kilometres. One of my primary concerns, when considering whether the restoration of Lake Pedder should go ahead, was with the scarring and with beaches hundreds of feet up the sides of mountains. Some people said, when giving evidence, that that would sort itself out over time, but I thought that there would be a massive cost involved and I could not be convinced that that would be satisfactorily resolved.

I also took into account the feelings of the people of Tasmania. When we were in Hobart to hear evidence, and during one of our lunch recesses, I spent some time loitering around a snack bar—as members can see by the size of me, I spend a considerable amount of my life loitering around snack bars—talking to the locals. I was saying how cold it was and they said, `Where are you from?' I said, `Western Australia,' and they said, `No doubt you would find it particularly cold here.'

There would have been about a dozen people there at that lunchtime. The gentleman behind the counter asked me what I was doing there. I said that I was from the federal parliament, on the Lake Pedder inquiry, and immediately the mood turned hostile. Someone behind the counter said to me, `Why don't you piss off and mind your own business?' When I suggested to someone who was giving evidence that the locals were pretty hostile to what was seen to be minding their business for them, the person said, `Oh, well, that is just a snack bar poll.' I have a suspicion—I suspect that some of the Tasmanian members on the committee would be able to back it up—that it is a widely held view in Tasmania that what we were doing was a waste of time and money, and something that we should not have been doing in the first place.

As I said in my maiden speech, if Abraham Lincoln could do the Gettysburg Address in less than two minutes I can say anything that I have got to say in just a few minutes. I would just like to conclude by thanking my colleagues on the committee, because it has by and large been a pleasant experience. I thank also the secretariat people for the diligence and hard work that they put in; I know that they had a pretty strict deadline that they were working to and in this report they really have done a magnificent job. They have been pleasant to work with all the time, sometimes under considerable duress—never more so than the day that we visited Lake Pedder. Whilst we were out at Scotts Peak dam we came across some people in distress and the chairman was asked if perhaps we could help them out.

I should point out that we were getting around in a minibus at that time. Being a large person, I went straight to the back seat and I was advised by colleagues who had been on many of these expeditions before not to sit behind the axle. I learnt that that was perfectly correct—it was a most uncomfortable trip. But I did not have any idea how uncomfortable it was to become. There was a group of army reservists who had been trekking in the Tasmania wilderness for something like a week. They had come down with a bad attack of gastric and were in a pretty debilitated state—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they failed to take any soap with them.

—They failed to take any soap with them and I do not think they had seen water for a long time, either. The chairman took mercy on them and stuffed them in the bus. Unfortunately, I was the only one in the back seat and I had two of them jammed alongside me with their backpacks. It was quite spectacular. It was enough to lift the plaque off your teeth!

PARA.TAB: By and all, with the good times and bad times that we shared, I am very happy to be associated with this report. No doubt the honourable member for Dunkley will tell us why he is unhappy to be associated with it. I commend the work that has been done by all of those on the committee and the secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lake Pedder was flooded in 1972 to develop further the hydro-electric schemes in Tasmania. At that time there was a beginning of environment groups all over the world and Lake Pedder in that respect was seen as a rallying cause for the green movement. Tasmanians too were beginning to be more aware of the environmental issues and the beginnings of the movement found a rallying issue in Lake Pedder.

PARA.TAB: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts undertook unanimously, I understand—with support from all sides of the House—to ask the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) for a brief to make a feasibility study. There had been a lot of interest in Lake Pedder over the years and there was a feeling, as we have heard this morning, that maybe the lake should be drained and taken back to its original form. There were members of the community that believed that.

The committee received its brief and I am sure that there were many positions held then within that committee. I thought the issue found a soft spot in many Tasmanians in days gone by. I dare say that today, if the same area were put up for flooding, there would be a much tougher passage. Alternatives to flooding a lake such as the original Lake Pedder would be found or at least looked at. However, with all that aside, the lake has gone from 20 square kilometres to 240 square kilometres. To drain it would leave about 24,000 hectares of mud that would need to be rehabilitated. That would be a mighty task and could not be taken lightly, and there would be a lot of possibilities of things going awfully wrong when such a task was undertaken.

I am certain that the committee took those issues pretty seriously when it reached its final conclusion. I know that the task of rehabilitation and trying to put it back together was in the minds of many of the members of the committee. I do not think that members of the committee realised how controversial this would be and some pretty wild assertions were made from many sides of this debate. This is still a very emotive issue in Tasmania and I am sure it is going to be for many years to come.

I asked to be involved in the committee when I realised that there were no Tasmanians on it, because this was of vital interest to the state and to the state's economy. At the same time, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) was also invited to be a part of the committee, and I welcomed the presence of another Tasmanian who could put the Tasmanian perspective into the committee deliberations.

There were one or two who took a shot at me for stating my position before I was invited on to the committee. However, nobody seemed to ask the other members of the committee what their feelings were before they sat on the committee. I know that some of them held views that the lake should be drained. There were many differences in attitude and orientation among members of the committee and it was a relief to find that, athough most could still talk and debate these issues, we had a wide diversity of opinions. That is quite a different matter with some people in the public on this debate where, if people do not get their own way, they sometimes take their bat and ball and go home. The Herald-Sun of 24 June said that the green groups are withdrawing from the regional forest agreement process. It is a very sad result for their decision making that they would do that.

The chairman says that he regrets having to come to the conclusion that the lake should not be drained but that he firmly considered that this was the recommendation that most fully reflects the responsibilities of the committee to all Australians and to Australia's natural environment. I know that it was at some cost that some members of the committee had to take this broader view, and I appreciate their deliberations and their approach to the work that took place on this committee. It was a job that was very hard to deal with objectively because it was about spending vast sums of money. The information required in order to make an informed decision was limited and there were many facts that were unavailable. A lot of what we had to deal with was conjecture.

The Hydro was quite detailed in its approach to the issue and had a number of concerns for the future supply of energy for Tasmania. The Tasmanian community, with the government and the opposition, played a vital role in the final decision making process. I think that the joint approach to the committee, in dealing with the Tasmanian economy, investment and people's confidence in the state, by both the government and the opposition, was important to the committee's deliberations.Without cooperation from this source, there may have been little the federal government could do if they had not been prepared to cooperate.

The Hydro-Electric Commission, with its position in the economics of Tasmania, is as much an icon as Lake Pedder is. Thousands of families have worked for the Hydro and its predecessor since 1895. It has been seen as a provider of jobs, security and quality of life and has been almost a father figure to generations of many thousands of Tasmanians. The lakes have been created with great significance. They have great significance in heritage terms. They are part of the state's working history and many thousands of people now enjoy the recreation of those lakes—including, of course, the new Lake Pedder.

Those people are concerned that, if one lake is drained, there will be nothing to stop others being targeted—and who will then provide the power to be used for the Tasmanian economy? Of course, Lake Pedder is part of a system that is linked together and its immediate neighbouring lake is Lake Gordon. I do not believe that you would drain Lake Pedder and then leave Lake Gordon where it is, touching that World Heritage area. If you took away Lake Pedder, what would happen to the industries that have settled in Tasmania? What would happen to the jobs that come from those industries? Those are questions that needed to be answered and that the committee had to deal with. That fear that I have talked about is a genuine fear; it is not something that can be taken very lightly and it had to be taken very seriously by the committee.

I think the decision is a very important one for Tasmania's strength in the future and may well come from a very sound grounding in our past. With this sort of infrastructure in place, we can be the providers of ample, clean power that is environmentally friendly, safe and sustainable for Tasmania for years to come. The inquiry was an interesting exercise and tested the ability of all the members of the committee. The report finally had one dissenter and I think that was marvellous, considering the nature of the issue and the nature of the views on the committee. It was a pleasure in that sense to work through the issues knowing that there was such a diverse range of views on the committee.

I congratulate the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and the staff of the committee. The chairmanship was outstanding in working through the different issues and the staff deserve thanks for their tedious work as well. I also thank the member for Langmore for his considerations to me. My task on that committee is now completed. While I would not say it was a pleasurable task, it was one that I am pleased to have participated in and it will be a part of my history. As I will be leaving the committee, I offer my best wishes for its deliberations in the future, especially in looking at the management of World Heritage areas, which will be a major undertaking. And I would like to commend this report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —11.33 a.m.)—When this report, The proposal to drain and restore Lake Pedder, was presented in the House on Monday I made some brief comments and I did commend both the chairman and the staff for their work. I also noted that it was quite an achievement to have this report presented prior to parliament rising for the winter recess, because it was very important that the report be out and that the matter be settled, once and for all, ahead of that two-month period. I want to continue now by restating some of the comments I made at that time. I believe that is necessary because of some of the interpretations that have been given by some people to the report and to the personal comments of the chairman, the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). I accept the right of the chairman to make those comments, but they were not the comments of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is unfortunate that, in the rush to get the report out, the summary that has been printed is an earlier version of the summary and does not reflect the tighter position of the committee which comes through in the text. So I recommend to anybody who does read the full report that they make sure they have the corrigendum or the correction summary as the basis for understanding what the committee is saying. The report and its recommendations are quite definite: that is, a definite `no' to any draining of Lake Pedder; and a definite `no' to any further assessment or provision of funds for the many areas of research that would be necessary before any serious consideration could be given to the proposal again.

The chairman stated in his press release that in his view it was an appalling mistake that Lake Pedder was originally dammed. At least one person in the media has taken that to mean that it was the view of the committee that it was an appalling mistake. Such was not the view of the committee. I am sure that it was the view of the chairman and perhaps one or two others, but it certainly was not the view of the committee and it certainly was not my view. Through all of this my view has been confirmed, if anything, that the damming of Lake Pedder was the correct decision for Tasmania then and remains so now.

The chairman said in the preface, also—as once again is his right and his responsibility—that he regretted that the committee was not able to come to any other conclusion. That was his view but not the view of the committee. The committee had no such view. As a member of the committee I myself had no regret at all that that was the conclusion, and I believe that was the view of many others of the committee.

Looking at the reasons for the conclusion, I think not all of those have been stated in media reports, either. There has been a certain interpretation made, that the committee was saying—as it was not—that if only more research money could be obtained then perhaps a different conclusion could be reached, and that the only reason why more research money could not be obtained was that there are more important environmental issues throughout Australia that need such money and take priority. The committee did indicate that more research would be needed before any assessment of whether or not it would be appropriate to drain—not whether to drain but whether it would be appropriate to look again at whether to drain. The committee also indicated that, in its view, it was of low priority to provide any further research funds. Even the environmentalists themselves stated so.

The committee said also, however—but this is not coming out in many of the reports of the recommendations of the committee—that there is no political consensus for Pedder to be drained. For a political consensus to occur would mean that both at the Tasmanian level and at the Commonwealth level there would have to be agreement. Tasmanians are firmly against the draining. Both of the major parties are opposed to it, and the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams), indicate—and, I presume, the comments of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) will indicate—that bipartisan approach of the major parties in Tasmania. I am told that the recent poll indicated that 85 per cent of Tasmanians are opposed.

It is not real to even give any thought to looking again at Pedder while there are those feelings in Tasmania, and it seems to me that they are going to be there for a long time. I think it does confirm the view of the Tasmanian government, which has been fairly critical of the whole inquiry, that it is not realistic for us at a federal level to be making these sorts of investigations on a serious basis unless there is some element of support from the state government. That is very much in our report, but it has not been coming through. There needs to be political consensus before we can seriously consider anything in this country.

There has also been a feeling that somehow or other the committee was of the view that it would have been nice to drain—in other words, the outcome of an argument definitely for or against. That was never put by the committee in any of its conclusions, and I for one, as I repeat, did not hear one argument which in my view was feasible and supported the draining of Lake Pedder as it is now.

In our consideration of the report and the question of Pedder, there are two fundamental facts that people have to remember. The first is that the original Lake Pedder was 10 square kilometres, and that included the dunes. The enlarged Lake Pedder, which we are talking about now, is 242 square kilometres. I do not think there is any real problem to any of us that the original Lake Pedder—that is, the 10 square kilometres—remains fundamentally in its original form.

So, when we are talking about or considering the draining and restoration of the enlarged Lake Pedder, the original Lake Pedder really is not an issue. The issue is whether or not the other 232 square kilometres, which was basically button grass plain, some rolling hills, a few steep cliffs and so forth, could be restored. There was a dramatic difference, in the evidence we received, between those who thought it could and those who thought it could not.

The second fundamental fact is that the Lake Pedder area was included in the World Heritage listing in 1982—10 years after the original Lake Pedder was flooded. In fact, the World Heritage listing was strengthened in 1989—17 years after the original Lake Pedder was flooded. So the question of World Heritage values in relation to draining Lake Pedder is, in my view, also not a real issue. There is some comment suggesting that the World Heritage values could be improved or enhanced if the enlarged Lake Pedder were drained. But draining it is really not an issue as to its World Heritage value, and there is no requirement under World Heritage for the enlarged Lake Pedder to be drained.

I do regret that the inquiry took place, because it has reopened some old wounds in Tasmania. That has been very obvious, given the reactions and comments that we had down there. It created a divisive situation in Tasmania at a time of economic difficulty in that state. It frightened potential investors, by creating doubt over one of Tasmania's major assets: environmentally friendly hydro power.

It has been said by one or two—and I acknowledge the Member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), and respect his right to say it—that too much time was spent on economic cost. I believe not enough time was spent on that, considering all of the economic aspects and, particularly, the total economic cost of draining Lake Pedder. We did look, in the narrow sense, at the cost of draining in relation to what it might cost to restore the 232 square kilometres that would be, once again, button grass plain and so forth. There is tremendous variation in those costs, and variation concerning whether or not restoration could actually take place. There is great doubt about that.

The slightly broader economic criterion was the cost of lost power. But we really did not address what economic value is derived from that power. That is what the real question is in Tasmania: the question of the employment, the wealth creation, the exports and so forth for Tasmania that come from utilising one of its major assets—hydro power. One could look at the number of employees that Comalco has for some evidence of that. Beyond Comalco, one could consider the fears expressed by the rapidly expanding salmon industry and a number of other industries which would see their futures put at risk by the draining of Lake Pedder.

In my limited time, I also want to dismiss three assumptions that are used by those proposing that Lake Pedder be drained. First of all, they assume that Lake Pedder itself is not significant in the total hydro power scheme structure in Tasmania, and that it holds only a very small percentage of the water of the total Gordon-Pedder system. Of course, that is one of the two dammed or storage systems for hydro power in Tasmania.

Those who say that do not understand what Lake Pedder is there for. Lake Pedder is a transfer dam. That is, it transfers water from one catchment to another: from the separate catchment of certain rivers, to the Gordon. It actually provides 42 per cent of the total amount of water in the Gordon scheme. It is the same as a lot of the dams in the Snowy Mountains scheme: they transfer water inland but, in themselves, they do not hold great amounts of water. So Lake Pedder is a very significant element in the hydro system in Tasmania and, in particular, in relation to drought proofing.

The second assumption was that Tasmania has a power surplus and that, therefore, the loss of the power from Pedder is not significant. Tasmania has a lower power surplus than almost any other state in Australia and yet we are not criticising those states with regard to power because they do have to have a safety factor in what is power generation. It is also assumed that power would not be needed. The latest advice we have from the Hydro-Electric Commission in a letter presented to the committee, and subsequently in a fax to me, is that discussions are taking place with companies which would require over 90 megawatts more of power. In fact, contracts have been signed with two companies which will require over 20 megawatts of power more than is presently used in Tasmania.

The third assumption was that Comalco is closing at Bell Bay anyway and that, therefore, the power will not be needed even for extra industry. To a certain extent that is based on the fact that there is reduced production at Comalco at the present time. So Comalco, in their view, is no longer serious about Tasmania. People neglect the fact that the reduction in production at Bell Bay is because of an international cartel—which this federal government supports—trying to cover the international surplus of aluminium production.

Comalco stated very clearly and definitely that it will close if Pedder is drained. Comalco has the option to either expand to a world scale operation at Bell Bay or to close. It is not there for just staying around. Remember that aluminium and alumina comprise the second largest export from this country and production units for aluminium around the world are becoming bigger and bigger.
In the remaining time I want to quote part of a fairly significant exchange between Dr Kjar of Comalco and the committee on 8 May 1995:
Dr Kjar—Taken in isolation, the draining of Lake Pedder would make it very difficult for us to proceed.
Mr LLOYD—That is, to go beyond the present capacity?
Dr Kjar—To proceed beyond the year 2001.
Mr LLOYD—Full stop?
Dr Kjar—Full stop.
CHAIR—Why is that?
Dr Kjar—Because we cannot see our way clear to expanding the facilities, to put money into a system that does not have the power to sustain us in the longer term.
Mr TRUSS—I take it you only have two options—either you expand or you close.
Dr Kjar—Yes, that is right.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is a window of opportunity for Comalco to expand to world scale in the next couple of years. Negotiations are under way between the HEC and Comalco. Those negotiations have had to be interrupted because of this inquiry and they can now proceed seriously. I wish both parties well for the future of Comalco in Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave a dissenting report and I believe what I have said in my dissenting report is correct. I would like to expand on the reasons why I gave that dissenting report. Firstly, I would like to read part of it so that it is recorded in Hansard. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: A large part of the evidence given to the Committee was on economic costs, and this I believe is the only arguments of the opponents to the proposal to restore Lake Pedder. What price is beauty? What price is a symbol that can inspire people forever? What price for the wonder of looking at a scene unspoilt by human intervention? What price to walk, and listen to the quiet? What price for the restoration of the soul? What price to admire the Creator's work? These prices were not computed in our report. Surely they outweigh other costs.

I truly believe that. I believe the committee report is another step along the way to the restoration of Lake Pedder. It will happen and it will happen through public pressure. At the present time in Tasmania the government and the opposition are opposed to the restoration of Lake Pedder. Governments and oppositions do not stay there forever. The people who are in the government change. Those people will one day be replaced by other people who, I can assure honourable members, will be more environmentally conscious than the existing people.

PARA.TAB: We have had some comments on the report from the Tasmanian government, which was quite vociferous in its abuse of the committee, right up to the tabling of the report. All the way through, the Tasmanian government used the inquiry unmercifully, to gain its own bit of publicity. However, when the time came to appear before the committee, the government squibbed it. One or two days before the members were due to appear before the committee, the Premier of Tasmania, Ray Groom, said that they would no longer be appearing before the committee because it was a charade and a farce, et cetera. He did not have the guts to come before this committee and put his arguments. Maybe he was scared of me. I do not know why: I am only one person on the committee, but—

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably so!

—It probably was the reason he did not appear. I can remember Ray Groom up in the old parliament: he used to have an office right opposite mine and we got on pretty well. He was quite a reasonable sort of person. Since he is an ex-Aussie Rules footballer and someone battling away out there who belonged to a team that did not always win the premiership but kept going, I thought that he would probably appear; but he squibbed it. The Tasmanian government came in for some criticism in our report, but I really believe that it should have come in for stronger criticism. Members of the Tasmanian government used their tactic, and they will use it time and time again in election campaigns, et cetera; but they did not have the guts to appear. The Mercury, a local paper in Tasmania said:

SPEECH.PARA: Premier Ray Groom said yesterday the Government and Hydro-Electric Commission had spent more than $350,000 providing information to the Federal Parliamentary committee and overall the inquiry would have cost more than $1 million.

That is just absurd, and it is typical of the sort of allegations that he would make. Straight off the top of his head, he dreams up a figure and says anything. That $350,000 might be what the HEC is charging the state government for putting all its submissions together.

PARA.TAB: I admit that it had done a lot of work on its submissions. It had brought out people from all over the world, and had an expert from California or somewhere, but these experts and the people that the Hydro-Electric Commission was paying were not experts who would come up with a unbiased opinion. If you are being paid X thousands of dollars for an opinion, naturally you are going to come up with one that suits your payer; and they definitely did. The chap from America came up with the figure of $2 1/2 billion dollars to restore Lake Pedder. That is completely outrageous and is complete rubbish.

Vast sums of money, it has been claimed, would be required to restore these 24,000 hectares buried under the mud. But it is not mud. If the people who made these comments read the report, they would see that there is hardly any mud there at all. Professor Tyler, who is an expert in this area, said there is a couple of millimetres of sediment from the actual lake. The original Lake Pedder had no mud or silt in it. All the water comes from the areas around it, and they are mud free: they are heath and button grass plains, et cetera. So this story about the mud is a load of rubbish, and the cost of restoring it is a load of rubbish.

We flew over the Gordon Dam on the day that we were at Lake Pedder, and the water level was the lowest it had been for 21 years. The level had been down for about 10 years, so there was a rim of earth all the way around the dam. If you fly over any dam when it is low, you will see a rim of dirt that has in the past been flooded, where all the plants have died. Such an area of dirt had been exposed above the waterline of the Gordon Dam, because there had been a drought in Tasmania. On that dirt, a huge number of young gum trees only six or seven feet high were growing. Nature had started to restore the area, and I am quite certain that that would happen in relation to this large area around Lake Pedder.

A lot of furphies have been put around concerning this subject and words have been used which are completely misleading. We heard people call the dams which were constructed by the Hydro-Electric Commission lakes. They are not lakes, they are dams. A dam is a dam and this is a damn dam. People played word games all the way through the inquiry. A petition about saving Lake Pedder was handed to members of the committee by someone who was on their way out to Lake Pedder. I said, `Yes, I'll take this. I'll save Lake Pedder.' I came to the committee with a biased view. I wanted to pull the plug on it and I will still do it. The petition was aimed at saving the present Lake Pedder. Can you imagine what would happen if that petition got out into the normal populace? If the petition got out there would be big signs saying `Save Lake Pedder' and the petitioners would get a lot of signatures. But the petition was not to save Lake Pedder; it was a petition to save Lake Pedder dam.

There are some points in the committee's report with which I disagree. It is claimed that the dam has rolling, drought proof hydro-electric power production. A power station has been built at Bell Bay and this power station does not rely on water. This power station is not used now. It is in mothballs because there is too much power in Tasmania. The power station at Bell Bay is the power station that could drought proof Tasmania, not the other power stations.

It is said that drainage of Lake Pedder would not necessarily result in increased tourism to Tasmania. The same comment was made during the campaign to stop the damming of the Franklin. One has only to go to Strahan to see the results of increased tourism. I have not seen it, but, from what I have been told, tourism to the area has increased dramatically. I can assure you that hardly any people go to look at Lake Pedder dam at the moment. When members of the committee visited the area we saw an ex-Hydro building which is being used as a guesthouse. I do not think that the guesthouse has too many customers.

If the dam on Lake Pedder is drained and the original lake is restored, there would be a huge increase in tourism and a restoration industry would be created. Thousands of people could be trained and they could do similar work all over the world. The University of Tasmania could set up a faculty of restoration ecology. Draining Lake Pedder would be a great benefit to the Tasmanian economy, but there are people in Tasmania who cannot see this. They are the people who, in similar words to those used by John F. Kennedy, say, `Some say why, and I say why not?' They are the people who say, `Why? Why do it?' Why do anything in this world? Some people have vision while others look only at the present day.

As I have said on many occasions, this lake will be restored. Restoration of the lake will create a lot of work in Tasmania and it will create worldwide interest. Restoration of the lake will give back to nature something that people have taken away. Restoration of the lake will show how far we as human beings have progressed in our consideration of the environment. Why do we need to say that we are right and that nature is wrong? Nature has been around for millions of years while we have only been here for the blink of an eyelid.

In a book written by the wife of Olegas Truchanas there are some beautiful words in relation to Tasmania. At the time the book was written, Olegas Truchanas was trying to save Lake Pedder from being inundated by people from the Hydro-Electric Commission and others, and he was giving speeches and talks in relation to Lake Pedder. The book was printed back in 1975 and is now out of print, but, in looking at the loan details at the back of the book, it can be seen that the book was borrowed frequently in the years from 1975 to 1977. Since then, the book was virtually unused until I took it out in 1995. That fact is quite interesting. It might be 20 years down the track since the book was written, but I assure you that it will not take 20 years to restore Lake Pedder to its original beauty. The book contains a speech that Olegas Truchanas made in 1971. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania is not the only place in the world where long-term, careful argument has been defeated by short-term economic advantage.
I repeat his words when I say that this is all about economics. He continued:

When we look round, the time is rapidly approaching when natural environment, natural unspoiled vistas are sadly beginning to look like left-overs from a vanishing world. This vanishing world is beautiful beyond our dreams and contains in itself rewards and gratifications never found in artificial landscape, or man-made objects, so often regarded as exciting evidence of a new world in the making.

The natural world contains an unbelievable diversity, and offers a variety of choices, provided of course that we retain some of this world and that we live in the manner that permits us to go out, seek it, find it, and make these choices. We must try to retain as much as possible of what still remains of the unique, rare and beautiful. It is terribly important that we take interest in the future of our remaining wilderness, and in the future of our National Parks. Is there any reason why, given this interest, and given enlightened leadership, the ideal of beauty could not become an accepted goal of national policy? Is there any reason why Tasmania should not be more beautiful on the day we leave it, than on the day we came? We don't know what the requirements of those who come after us will be. Tasmania is slowly evolving towards goals we cannot now see. If we can revise our attitudes towards the land under our feet; if we can accept a role of steward and depart from the role of conqueror; if we can accept the view that man and nature are inseparable parts of the unified whole—then Tasmania can be a shining beacon in a dull, uniform and largely artificial world.

That has not changed. Those words are more important now than when he said them in 1975. Tasmania is a unique place on this planet, and we are destroying it slowly by woodchipping and damming beautiful lakes. We can restore one area of Tasmania to how it was. We can leave it to nature to restore it; and I believe nature will restore it, given time. One only has to look at past devastations. Look at Mount St Helens volcanic eruption a few years ago: life is returning there quite rapidly, and life will return to this area of Lake Pedder. I can assure this House that I will do all I can to assist it. I will continue, in whatever capacity I can, to return something to nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand here as a proud Tasmanian to discuss the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation an the Arts inquiry into the proposal to drain and restore Lake Pedder. I mean that in the best sense of the term, even though the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has mentioned a whole range of issues quite outside this report. I would like to concentrate for a few minutes on one of the comments which the honourable member for Dunkley has mentioned: the line from Olegas Truchanas that we ought to be good stewards versus conquerors.

PARA.TAB: Tasmania, taken as an economic unit in the world, has more of its area in World Heritage reserve than any other country in the world. If we take Tasmania as a country and measure it against Brazil, the United States, Canada, the old Soviet Union, Nigeria and so on, right through the whole world, Tasmania comes in ninth in the area that is reserved; but as a percentage, it has double the figure of any other country in the world. Twenty per cent of Tasmania is in World Heritage reserve, and 30 per cent is totally reserved.

To give people in the other states an idea of what that means in regard to the mainland states and territories, it is like taking all of Queensland, all of New South Wales and all of Victoria and making that a total reserve in regard to heritage values. That is what it would mean. I say to people from other states, `If you want to keep leg-roping Tasmania's capacity to have an economically viable future for its citizens, first of all clean up your own act and reserve as much of your state as we have done.' That is what I say to Victorians. Because people in other states have failed, they now try to impose their views on Tasmania. I say to the other states, `You take up the flag and be a good steward of your own state, without looking over the fence and trying, because you have failed, to impose your views on Tasmania.'

I just say, `Do what Tasmania has done. We have got 30 per cent of our state in reserves forever—for our kids, for the world.' I notice that the environment committee's reference now is for the management of World Heritage areas. We have a great World Heritage area, it includes Lake Pedder, and the committee has just decided: do not drain Lake Pedder, and do not investigate it further. That is the commonsense view of all the information that was given to us—all the information. In fact, we had some people come to us and say, `We have had a look at this lake. In other parts of the world, this is the sort of lake we are trying to recreate. It has got absolutely clean beautiful water, beautiful scenery. This is what we are trying to remake in the rest of the world and here you are thinking of draining it. We cannot understand it.' And that is pretty true.

If you go down to Lake Pedder, there is beautiful scenery that is marvellous and very attractive in world terms. In fact, it is part of the World Heritage area—that is how beautiful it is. As a committee, we had to consider whether we ought to take the risk of draining it and ending up with a doughnut out there in the World Heritage area forever. It might have ended up as a large area, of 232 square kilometres, with quite different vegetation if it could have been restored adequately—and there was some doubt about that. Even the leader of the Greens in the Tasmania parliament said that she did not think it would even start to be restored within 25 years. Now you have to start to think what this peat is going to look like after 25 years of getting about 100 inches of rainfall every year on it. Is it going to stay there? We do not know that. I would hope that it would. But there was the possibility that there would be disaster if we took the water away and there would be this large area left that was denuded of plant life.

The other aspect to this debate is that decisions have been made in regard to this area of Tasmania. We do have a reservoir there for hydro power. Another important debate about the environment in this world is about the greenhouse effect and the cleanest power source in the world—apart from solar energy, I guess—is hydro power. Tasmania makes a great contribution to Australia because it does not use coal, it does not send up sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere. Why? Because we have a hydro power system which allows the water to run free and Lake Pedder is an integral part of that power system.

It has been debated whether Tasmania has an oversupply of power. I must say that over the 10 years or so in which I have been involved in federal parliament I have met a number of business people, and their big doubt has always been: `Will a state government be able to guarantee the supply of power if we come?' They have said, `Will the Tasmanian state government guarantee it, and can you guarantee that the federal Labour Party and the federal government will not intervene and create difficulties environmentally?' There have been various companies over the years who have looked at Tasmania very seriously. But they decided the risk was far too great during the mid-1980s, because of the environmental debate in Australia, and they moved away. As a consequence, maybe now there is an appearance of an oversupply. But as the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has said, the oversupply in Tasmania is less than in any other state. So I cannot see how that is a valid argument in this particular issue.

I come back to the important point in regard to the future of this committee: the management of World Heritage areas. In Australian terms, Tasmania has a very large World Heritage area but it has not been funded adequately to give good management to this World Heritage area. When we were looking at draining Lake Pedder, the interesting point came up about the actual ecology of the lake as it is now. The lake does have a very enlarged platypus population and, no doubt, if we surveyed the populations of other animals that are now living in that lake area, there would be increased populations of a great diversity of species.

If the lake was drained, what would happen to the ecology and the ecosystem that exists there now? The environmental movement has argued for 20 years in Australia that we cannot intervene and that we must maintain the ecosystems that exist. There is an ecosystem in Lake Pedder now and why should that not be kept? Why should we take the risk of killing 2,000 or 3,000 platypuses, or however many there are? Why should we take that risk? There is no answer to that and I think this was one of the turning points in the debate, certainly within Tasmania. The Tasmanian people woke up to the argument which they had been fighting for 20 years with the radical Green movement. I say the radical Green movement because there has been a change in consciousness about the environment in the world and I welcome that because I think we are all the better for it. At the same time, commonsense has to be shown when there is an issue such as Lake Pedder. The majority report, which was 13 to one, was a commonsense decision.

Lake Pedder is a beautiful lake, albeit through man-made intervention. A lot of things that men and women do in this world make the world a better place. Sometimes, we improve what nature does. We are part of nature. I reject the idea of the last speaker, the member for Murray, that nature is on one side and people are on the other. We are part of nature. We are integrated with nature and we ought to be good stewards. That is our role: to be good stewards of nature. I believe that Tasmania is doing a very good job of that.

The committee, on balance, looked at the whole range of issues. It understood the argument that, previously, this was a beautiful natural area of Tasmania. However, we have moved on. A lake has been created and it would be far too great a risk to drain the lake. It is a slim possibility that any benefits would arise. The committee decided that there would be no value in this. I reject the notion that this lake will be drained because, I think, as time goes on, this committee's report will be reflected on. The committee gathered all the information which was available to us as members of the Australian federal parliament. We came down with the very clear conclusion, 13 to one, that this lake should not be drained, nor should it have any further assessment. I think that is a wise decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ever!
—Ever!
—That's a long time!
—Well, it is, Barry. Obviously, people in the future will make their own judgments about a whole range of things in the world, and I understand that.
—It is not that far in the future either.

—That is a matter for the debate. This part of Tasmania, including the lake, is World Heritage quality. It is a beautiful area and well worth visiting. I have spent some time holidaying and travelling around down at the lake. We have are many mornings like this one in Canberra—nice, brisk, with frost and beautiful clear skies—down at Lake Pedder. It is just absolutely supreme.

PARA.TAB: Mr Horne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the platypuses just bubbling around in the water; it is just beautiful.
—You sound like Professor Forteath.

—They just sort of dabble around. Their tails come up and they look around for a little while. When they notice something foreign there, down they go and up come the bubbles. After a while, a few come up and even some little ones come up. It is marvellous, absolutely beautiful, and it is quiet. It is away from all of the nonsense, the telephones and the noise of the machines in our society and our cities. All there is down there is the hum of nature.
—It sounds as good as the Barrier Reef.
—It is as good as the Barrier Reef.
—What about the speedboats?

—Yes, the Barrier Reef does have a few speedboats. I have been on the environment committee for years now and I have also been deputy chairman of it. I will not be on this committee after the conclusion of this. We have set aside our World Heritage areas in Australia; now let us make sure that we resource them so that people can go and see them. Let us also make sure that we do not create problems for nature in those areas by having people visit them. It is no good having these beautiful areas if they are not accessible to people. One of the arguments for setting them aside is so that people can go there to `re-create their soul,' as many would say, and be able to dwell on nature. And nature—the absolute beauty of it—can have that effect on people. I do not deny that; in fact, I affirm that. As somebody who has lived in the bush a lot of his life, I enjoy nature. It is fabulous.

PARA.TAB: This part of Tasmania is like the Kakadu of the south of Australia. It is beautiful and it is unique. It is a wonderful experience to be down there and to be able to enjoy the solitude and the quietness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Platypus Dundee.
—Platypus Dundee. I think that is probably a good way of putting it. As I said, the Kakadu of the south, Platypus Dundee, call it what you like—
—You can play the leading role.
—Beg your pardon?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Order! The member will not respond to interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a marvellous report. (Time expired)

—As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I am wondering whether the previous speaker, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), and I are talking about the same report. I can assure the House that I do not know, and no-one knows, whether Lake Pedder is full of platypus but I can guarantee that his argument is full of red herrings, and that was the thing that we faced throughout the whole of this inquiry. With our limited resources, with our limited time, there is no doubt that we came up with a report that is very inconclusive. It is disappointing, it is predictable, but there is no doubt it is inconclusive.

PARA.TAB: I certainly do not read into this report the fact that Lake Pedder will never be drained. I support the theory that Australia could set itself apart and show the world that we are truly leaders and we truly care for the environment by placing the draining of Lake Pedder at the pinnacle of priorities and then attempting to do it. Everywhere we turned, we were given what I believe was disinformation; certainly, there was a lack of information. Let us face it, the people in Tasmania live on a furphy. They understand that hydro-electricity is giving them cheap electricity, supporting industry and creating employment. That is furphy No. 1.

The Tasmanian people have the third most expensive electricity in Australia. At a time when small business is the major employer in Australia, the Tasmanian government is fully supporting maintaining Lake Pedder and providing electricity to an aluminium smelter at subsidised rates. At the same time, it is saying to the rest of the Tasmanian people, `You will have to pay high prices for your electricity to subsidise this smelter.'

The thing that we could not determine, that we were not told, is whether Comalco is going to stay in Tasmania or not. The Tasmanian government has given it an assurance that it will continue to provide it with cheap electricity. Our report is not conclusively saying one way or another whether Lake Pedder should be drained. So it has the guarantee that Lake Pedder will stay there, it has the guarantee that electricity will continue to be cheap. But there will be other factors that will determine in the next couple of years whether Comalco will quit Tasmania or not. The chances are they probably will. If that does happen, I would see that as a major factor in forming the future for Tasmania, a future which would be considerably rosier without that smelter than it is today with the smelter. Suddenly, it would give the Tasmanians the drive to go out and seek small business and small industries to come to Tasmania. They could offer them cheaper electricity than they are currently able to get from the HEC.

The other furphy, of course, is that Lake Pedder is there to drought proof the hydro-electric system in Tasmania. It does not do that, because we can only use 1.6 metres of the water that is currently stored in this 242 square kilometre artificial lake. If there is a need to draw down the water of Lake Pedder more than that 1.6 metres differential, then the Tasmanian government has to meet and it has to pass special legislation. In the last 10 years of drought that has existed in Tasmania, that has not been necessary. So the water that is stored in Lake Pedder has not been used to drought proof the hydro-electric scheme and it certainly does not appear that it is going to be.

As I said, there are a great many furphies—all this uncertainty. When the committee proposed a positive step saying, `Let us look at the possibilities of doing something exciting, something positive in relation to the environment,' it was always the question of the unknown, the fact that `We believe this to be so, but we can't prove it and you can't prove it.' It was said, `If you want to drain the lake, you cannot prove that the original lake is going to be restored.' Of course, no-one knows whether the original lake is going to be restored to its original condition, but I do say this: it would be very exciting to try. It would be a symbol for the world to say that, for the first time in history, a small nation such as Australia has the courage to say that there is more to this world than economics, and that this world needs to make sure that it conserves environmental factors that will maintain a living standard suitable for all species, not only the human species.

We heard this rubbish about platypus. Now some people seem to think that platypus are fish. Platypus are air breathing mammals, they are monotremes. They are not spread homogeneously throughout a lake; they are animals that nest in the banks. I can assure honourable members that the middle of Lake Pedder is no environment to go and catch a platypus. They would be found around the banks of the lake. Of course, there has been no mention about the millions of trout, the introduced species, that are there and the harm that they are doing to natives that may also live in that water. We accept that as a fact. Everywhere we turned we were given misinformation. We were told, `You can't prove that, you don't know.' So unfortunately I believe that the report is very predictable.

I believe that the economic argument to retain Lake Pedder is completely false. Unfortunately, we had to pay credence to it. At no time could we be told what Comalco is paying for electricity; that is confidential information. I respect that, but I believe that the government of Tasmania did have the right and the responsibility to come and meet with our committee. Yet a day before we were due to meet with that government it elected not to come and speak with the committee. Personally, if I were a Tasmanian I would think that the effrontery of that government was intolerable in such an important issue as this. The people of Tasmania have a right to expect that their government will lay all the cards on the table in this very important issue.

I have no doubt that, if the people who dammed Lake Pedder in 1972 had had to go through the same course and to answer all of the questions that are being asked of the proponents that the lake be drained, the lake would never have been dammed in the first place. I have no doubt about that. I would just point out that Edward St John, who carried out the inquiry into Lake Pedder and its damming in 1974—and who was not from this side of politics—said, `Our children will undo the crimes that we have done.' That was his opinion of what the damming of this lake meant.

It certainly was a major change to a wilderness area. It certainly was a major change to a very sensitive ecosystem. I believe all right thinking Australians owe it the world to say, `We are prepared to have a go to right that wrong decision.'

Throughout our inquiry we kept getting statements such as that the erosion would have changed it—of course the erosion will have changed it—and that we would never get the button grass or the same ecosystem re-establishing. I do not know that, and the people who propose that do not know it either, because it has never been done. But how interesting to try. How interesting simply to carry out an experiment and draw down the lake a couple of metres to see what the natural process of regeneration would allow. We heard all about how introduced plant species would take over, and the weeds would dominate. There was no proof, but the committee had to listen to that. We had to pay credence because similarly we could not say that it would not happen.

Obviously, there would have to be human intervention. I believe that that human intervention had the potential to be minimal. But how exciting to say to a group of horticulturists, `Let us see what we can see and show the way to the world.' We are not going to do that, and I am a bit saddened. I certainly hope that in years to come the Australian parliament will debate this issue again. I would like it to be in my lifetime; it might not be. The children of Australia should not be discouraged by this report. They should take this report and say that it has enormous potential.

Since the report came out, I have spoken with some of the people who gave evidence before our committee. They supported the draining of Lake Pedder. They are not disheartened by the report. They see it as being relatively neutral. There is lots of information in the report that they will be able to use in their arguments in the future. I encourage them to do so. I am proud of having participated in the inquiry. I am proud of some of the questions that I asked of the people who gave evidence. I am extremely disappointed with the result.

TALK.START.PARA: —You signed the report.
—I know, but I can still be disappointed. I did not think that my not signing it would achieve anything.
—A real man of principle.

—Unfortunately, you did not hear the majority of my speech. You could not afford the time. But you were one of the people—if you care to read Hansard—that I referred to. While we could not prove our side of the argument, there is no doubt that you could not prove yours either. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Mr Bilney:
That the House take note of the papers:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS) delivered its findings and recommendations in a classified report that was submitted to the government on 31 March 1995. The commission was constituted by the Hon. Gordon Samuels AC, QC and Mr Michael Codd AC. The public report—also known as the Samuels report—was tabled on 1 June. It summarises the commissioners' findings and recommendations on the grievances of two former ASIS officers and on the overall accountability and management of ASIS.

PARA.TAB: I will comment on the two major recommendations of the commission. The first recommendation is that ASIS should be given a legislative basis to replace the existing executive authority. The Samuels report said that legislation would reassure the public and dispel the persistent mythology that ASIS is unaccountable. The second major recommendation of the Samuels report is that ASIS should be brought under the scrutiny of a parliamentary committee. This proposal has the potential to have a more substantial impact on the management of ASIS.

The commission recommended that the proposed committee should combine with the Joint Statutory Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and that it should have the power to initiate its own inquiries, except in operationally sensitive matters.

Legislation and parliamentary scrutiny are two of the ways suggested by the commission to provide a compromise between ASIS's need for security and the free flow of information in the public arena. I do not propose to discuss the government's contentious proposal to jail journalists who disclose sensitive information. That does not mean that I agree with it—only that it is a subject for another day.

In 1977, ASIS, established by executive direction on 13 May 1952, was publicly acknowledged by the Australian government as Australia's foreign intelligence agency. It is responsible for the covert foreign intelligence collection, of which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) spoke in his statement of 22 July 1992. Its intelligence collectors are stationed overseas and, because of sensitivity, details of its operations are not revealed.

In the report, the commission described in some detail the process of accountability for ASIS. The Samuels report sets out the government endorsed definition of accountability—one which emanates from the Australian Public Service. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of the relationship between public servants, secretaries of departments and ministers, and ministers and the Parliament, accountability is defined as existing where there is a direct authority relationship within which one party accounts to a person or body for the performance of tasks or functions conferred, or able to be conferred by that person or body.

The accountability obligations of public officials and bodies are met through controls. According to the commissioners, `control' means that an individual or body is subject to an institution's or a person's oversight, direction or request that they provide information on their action, or justify it before a review authority. Information is central to effective control and accountability relationships. An individual or body can be held to account only by those who have access to relevant information on performance.

PARA.TAB: During the inquiry, the Director-General of ASIS and senior government officials all accepted that ASIS should be part of the system of public accountability with appropriate modifications to meet security needs. There are extensive arrangements for the accountability and control of ASIS within the executive government and the evidence presented to the commissioners is that they have been exercised effectively since the second Hope royal commission.

Under existing arrangements the basis for the control and accountability of ASIS within the executive government is the directive issued to the director-general by the minister for foreign affairs after it was endorsed by the security committee of cabinet. It sets out the functions of ASIS and proscribes one former function: training for, or carrying out, covert action.

It requires that ASIS obey Australian law and that its activities conform to the foreign policy of the government of the day. The directive places ASIS under the control of the director-general, subject to the directions of the minister for foreign affairs. It authorises the director-general, subject to the approval of the Prime Minister, to brief the Leader of the Opposition.

The director-general is personally responsible for all key operational decisions. The effectiveness of the control and accountability of ASIS depends crucially on the competence of both the minister and the director-general and the trust between them. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has no controlling role over ASIS in a managerial or operational sense. The commissioners found an extensive, thorough and effective web of checks and balances within the internal management of operations.

Another form of accountability within the executive government is ASIS's position in relation to the Office of National Assessments, which reports annually on the performance of the intelligence collection agencies, including ASIS. However, the service has been subject to little direct scrutiny from outside the executive government. The need for operational secrecy has meant that the normal instruments of external accountability—direct parliamentary scrutiny and oversight by the Auditor-General—do not apply fully to ASIS.

Such parliamentary oversight as exists is subject to government control. The government can refuse access to necessary information, as with the policy of neither confirming nor denying non-official claims about the security and intelligence agencies. Scrutiny of the budget and other aspects of agency operations by parliamentary committees, particularly Senate estimates committees, provides a mechanism for oversight of the public sector. However, little use has been made of this technique in respect of ASIS. The service is funded through a one-line entry in the appropriation bills and budget papers, but ASIS officers do not attend Senate estimate committee hearings. No other parliamentary committees have examined ASIS's activities or administration.

Other opportunities for limited external accountability include the provision in the directive for the Leader of the Opposition to be briefed by the director-general and the auditing of ASIS's non-operational accounts by the Auditor-General. ASIS has never been subject to a performance audit by the Auditor-General in any area of its work.

The Samuels report recognised that an intelligence agency cannot carry out many of its legitimate functions, and thus serve the interests of national security, without a high level of secrecy about its operations, personnel and techniques. At the same time, many of the foreign intelligence agencies of other countries now face more comprehensive systems of control and accountability than does ASIS.

In particular, the comparable agencies in the United States and the United Kingdom both have a statutory base and formal relationships with review committees of their legislatures. The Canadian Security Intelligence Service, which has only domestic security functions, has been subject to oversight by an independent statutory committee of privy councillors since 1984 and, more recently, has come under the oversight of a parliamentary subcommittee. As a matter of principle, agencies which exercise the powers and use the resources which Australians give their government should be accountable to the Australian community for their actions. There is no doubt that ASIS must become subject to public sector accountability standards. The accountability mechanisms must, however, be appropriately modified to take account of the need for operational secrecy.

In the context of accountability within the executive government, the commissioners concluded in their report that the accountability and control of a secret organisation with sensitive functions should not depend to the extent that it presently does on the personal characteristics and capabilities of the minister for foreign affairs and the Director-General of ASIS and the relationship between them.

The commissioners also found that it was desirable that external accountability for ASIS be enhanced because the service exercises significant governmental powers. The Samuels report quotes the words of Mr Justice Hope that the fundamental consideration favouring legislative authority for ASIS is that:

SPEECH.PARA: Parliament is the instrument of democratic control of government in this country.

In the report of the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security of 1977, Mr Justice Hope recommended the statutory incorporation of ASIS, the principal advantage being the conferral of legitimacy. In this report His Honour said:

Legislation, by giving the service a proper role assigned to it by Parliament, would establish it as part of the family of government. It would thereby favourably improve its efficiency and effectiveness, and, by removing a cause of unease amongst some of its officers, enhance its morale.

While the legislation could not be expected to say with any particularity how and under what conditions ASIS should operate in Australia to collect foreign intelligence, save in compliance with Australian law, Mr Justice Hope believed that it was worthwhile to obtain from parliament:
. . . the maximum authority and control consistent with the essential need for secrecy . . .
It became clear during the course of the Samuels inquiry that ASIS itself was keen to be placed on a legislative basis. The service submitted that:
The present legal basis of the Service may no longer be as appropriate as it once was

. This, together with the policy of not commenting on allegations about ASIS, may lead to concern among members of the public and Parliament that ASIS is somehow `out of control'. Greater transparency in regard to the already extant oversight and accountability arrangements for ASIS is, in the Service's view, easily achieved and would allay what concerns there are in the Parliament, Government and the wider community. A statutory basis for ASIS would enhance both the sense and the reality of its accountability.

The commissioners concluded that legislation to continue ASIS in existence and to provide authority for its activities is desirable in principle and will be of benefit in practice. I respectfully agree with that conclusion.

PARA.TAB: Clearly the content of such legislation would have to be carefully considered and drafted in order for it to serve its purposes. I note that the government response to the Samuels report foreshadows the introduction of legislation at the earliest practical opportunity. I urge the government to give the appropriate priority to this task and to provide a draft of the proposed legislation to the coalition for examination as soon as possible.

The Samuels report recommended that, if the parliament is to approve ASIS's charter by passing legislation, the parliament should also be able to review the way in which the charter is put into practice. One way to accomplish this is through parliamentary committee scrutiny. The commissioners considered that any committee to oversee ASIS would itself require a legislative base, including provisions to address security concerns by setting limits to the disclosure of information and prescribing penalties for unauthorised disclosure. The commissioners were of the view that, given an appropriate legislative base, Australian and overseas experience suggest that security could reasonably be assured. In the US, the Central Intelligence Agency answers to permanent select committees and to separate appropriation committees of each house of Congress; it is subject to the Intelligence Oversight Act 1980 and to accountability provisions in its own statute, the National Security Act 1947. Members of the select committees, which have wide powers of oversight and review, are appointed by the presiding officers of the respective houses, subject to maximum terms of membership for six years for the house committee and eight years for the senate committee.

Each committee is given access, under secure conditions, to extensive information on intelligence activities. One function of the select committees is to authorise the CIA's annual budget, separately from the work of the appropriation committees. In this lengthy process, the CIA is required to provided detailed justification of its budget to each committee. The commissioners observed that this power over the CIA's budget greatly strengthens the capacity of the committees to oversee the agency.
