There is no formal limit to the information which the committees can request. In practice, limits to access have been negotiated between them and the CIA. The committees are told in general terms about the methods used, the types of operations conducted and the sources which the CIA has. Particular sources and methods are not identified except in exceptional circumstances, when the information will be confined, for example, to a senior staff member and the chair and ranking minority member of the committee.

The general counsel to the senate select committee told Commissioner Samuels that he had not, in eight years of working for the committee, encountered an information problem which he could not negotiate satisfactorily with the CIA. Commissioner Samuels found that comments about the congressional oversight system in the US were overwhelmingly positive, despite the significant administrative burden which the system imposes on the CIA.

There was a strong theme of accountability which was reinforced by congressional oversight. The congressional oversight apparently helps the CIA to do its job better. Commissioner Samuels found that having to account to congressional communities concentrates the minds of managers in the agency, who pay attention to detail as a result.

Further, Congress has become the advocate for the intelligence agencies, which have no other constituency; it legitimises the intelligence budget and is a layer of support and protection for the agencies. In addition, the commissioner learnt that the congressional committees have a very good record of not leaking, with the result that the intelligence community has become progressively more trusting of them.

In the United Kingdom, the intelligence and security committee was established in 1994 by the Intelligence Services Act. Its function is to examine the expenditure and administration policy of the security service, secret intelligence service and government communications headquarters.

The committee consists of nine members of parliament—none of them ministers—who are appointed by the Prime Minister after consultation with the Leader of the Opposition. Information sought by the committee can be withheld if it is sensitive information, defined as information which might lead to the identification of sources, other assistance or operational methods, information about particular operations, or information supplied by another government, where that government does not consent to its disclosure. Information may also be withheld from the committee where the foreign minister has determined that it should not be disclosed, but the minister may not make such a determination on the grounds of national security alone. Sensitive information may be disclosed to the committee if the government considers it safe to do so.

The British committee has several distinct features. First, it is not a parliamentary committee, since its members are appointed by the Prime Minister and not elected by the parliament. Secondly, the committee reports to the Prime Minister, rather than to parliament, although the Prime Minister is required to table at least an edited version of the committee's reports. Thirdly, the committee is staffed from the cabinet office by a member of the staff of the intelligence coordinator and not by the staff appointed by the committee, as would ordinarily be the case. These arrangements are intended to ensure high-calibre membership of the committee. Other comparisons can be made with the Canadian domestic body—the Canadian Security Intelligence Service—but, in the interests of time, I will not—(Extension of time granted) I am indebted to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I am certainly indebted to the member for Chifley (Mr Price).

Canada does not have a foreign intelligence collection agency. The domestic security service is subject to extensive arrangements for accountability to the parliament. The legislation regulating the Canadian Security Intelligence Service provides for a permanent Security Intelligence Review Committee with oversight functions. SIRC reports annually to the Canadian parliament. Its members are all privy councillors, an office usually, but not exclusively, reserved for former cabinet ministers. In recent times, the members of SIRC have been respected citizens who have been created privy councillors for the purpose.

The Canadian parliament also has a subcommittee of the parliament's justice committee which operates as the subcommittee on national security. This is not a standing committee and has to be established by each parliament. The subcommittee's role is to review and consider the management and operations of CSIS and SIRC. The subcommittee has no legislative framework and so defines its own functions and powers by evolution. The subcommittee relies on the prerogatives of the parliament to require individuals to appear or produce documents.

In the light of those overseas experiences, the commissioners examined several models for a parliamentary committee to oversee ASIS. The commissioners favoured a standing joint statutory committee with a broad charter to review the activities, expenditure and administration of ASIS, exercising its functions principally through in camera hearings. The committee would have sufficient access to information to assure effective oversight, but that access would be under secure conditions and subject to rules capable of preventing release of information without authority.

The commissioners recommended that a single intelligence and security committee cover both ASIS and ASIO. The commissioners recommended that the membership be small—a maximum of six if the committee were to cover ASIS only, or eight if the committee were established to oversee both ASIS and ASIO. Membership would be divided equally between the government and non-government parties and drawn from both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The government chair would have a deliberative and a casting vote.
As well as conducting the review of the activities, expenditure and administration of ASIS, the commissioners said that the committee could conduct specific inquiries on its own initiative.

In its response to this recommendation of the Samuels report, the government accepted in principle the value of limited parliamentary oversight of ASIS. However, the government does not fully accept the model proposed by the commissioners for the parliamentary committee. The government favours separate oversight committees for ASIS and for ASIO, due to the different activities of the two agencies, instead of a combined committee. The government agrees with the size and make-up of the committee as recommended in the Samuels report, but prefers a limited role for the committee. It proposes that the committee secretariat be security-cleared and seconded from the executive government.
The government said in its response to the report that the committee's role would be:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to review the expenditure and administration of ASIS, and ASIS's compliance with Australian law and other rules and procedures.

The government also confirmed that, while it proposed amending the ASIS directive in line with other recommendations of the Samuels report, the modifications would largely be consequential on the enactment of legislation and would not entail any alteration to ASIS's basic functions and powers. The government has said:

ASIS will still be prevented from carrying out, or training to carry out, covert action, by which we mean interference in the internal affairs of other countries by means of paramilitary action or covert interference in politics.

Given that statement, the role of the parliamentary committee must be sufficiently wide to ensure that it can examine allegations of non-compliance with that requirement. It is by no means clear that this would come within the government's phrase of `compliance with Australian law and other rules and procedures'. To this extent, the government's response to the recommendations of the Samuels report is inadequate. The recommendation of the commissioners as to the committee's role, particularly in relation to the initiation of inquiries, is preferable. The tension between, on the one hand, examination of allegations of non-compliance with the covert action ban and, on the other hand, the restriction on the examination of sensitive operational matters would have to be resolved in a practical way.

PARA.TAB: The experience in the United States of America suggests that too much commitment to the intelligence services by a parliamentary committee might be more of a problem than would too much independence, with the result that the intelligence oversight committee becomes captured by the intelligence agencies. This has been described by one writer as the result of `the seductiveness of secrets'. Indeed, Justice Hope referred to the hazards for committee members of knowing too much, and thereby feeling a shared responsibility for outcomes, and he gave this as a reason for restricting a committee's access to some types of information.

As I said earlier, Commissioner Samuels observed that most of the Congress intelligence committees have taken an advocative approach on behalf of the intelligence services. This lends support to the argument that parliamentary involvement in ASIS as well as ASIO could help to generate public support for those services, at a time when changes in the strategic situation might seem to make such services less necessary.

I strongly commend to the government the proposals in the Samuels report for the introduction of a legislative basis for the existence and operation of ASIS and for the establishment of a joint statutory parliamentary committee which will oversee ASIS in an appropriate way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: I am very pleased that I was able to secure the call, and I would like to commend the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) for his contribution on ASIS this afternoon, which has been no less than his normal well-considered contribution to the debates in this place. Firstly, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you may recall that there were some very serious allegations made by some former officers of ASIS, allegations which were taken up in particular by a Four Corners program. I thought that I should read into the Hansard record one of the comments in the Samuels report. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: To take the Four Corners program as an example, the introduction promised stories of `Australia's disturbing secret involvement in wars, coups and political intrigue'. But the level of factual accuracy about operational matters was not high—neither here nor in other media reports. Indeed, to paraphrase a book review attributed to A E Houseman, `what was disturbing was not true, and what was true was not disturbing'.

It is important that we should offer that reassurance to the Australian people about those wild allegations. I concur with the report's suggestion that there should be adequate parliamentary review of ASIS. Unlike a lot of members of parliament, I have had the opportunity previously to be briefed by Mr Furner, the Director-General, as he then was, in charge of ASIS, so I know a little, but not a lot, of the good work that it does.

PARA.TAB: I do not altogether accept the government's proposition that there needs to be a separate committee. I am certainly of the view that there could be a joint standing committee of the parliament charged with oversighting both ASIS and ASIO. I concur with the comments that there is a danger as far as committee members are concerned in dealing with intelligence matters. One criticism I make of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is that we are too bipartisan in that we get too attached to defence and sometimes we are just not critical enough.

If that is a problem in the defence area, I am sure it would be more so in the intelligence area. I must say it would be one of the committees of the parliament, and we do have them, where a great deal of bipartisanship would need to operate to make it successful. I think a key factor would be that, if at any stage there was any irresponsibility in terms of leaking some of the information that was put before that committee, it would do great damage to the standing of the committee and the operation of the committee.

The report recommends that there should be a legislative framework for ASIS, and I certainly strongly concur with that recommendation. I am very pleased to see that the government has picked up and agreed to the recommendation. But, as pointed out by the honourable member for Tangney, we have yet to actually see the draft bill. As is not uncommon in these matters, there seems to be a lengthy delay between a decision to legislate, the preparation of drafting instructions and the actual production of the bill itself. Hopefully, we can anticipate that we will be able to have that legislation debated and enacted before the parliament is dissolved for other more exciting things. I certainly approve of the legislative basis.

I must also point out that it has been the practice in relation to ASIS that the Leader of the Opposition is routinely briefed on ASIS matters and shadow ministers are briefed on a needs basis on ASIS matters. That practice is a very important one and one which would continue under the recommendations of the report.

This report has shown that there has been no evidence whatsoever that ASIS has acted outside the guidelines imposed by the government. There is no evidence of any unauthorised activity which was carried in the more sensational reports in the media, and I frankly regret that those reports were ever made in the first place. It is interesting that we impose accountability standards on Public Service departments, we are imposing accountability standards on ASIS, but we live in a society—maybe this is an important feature of our society—where the media can irresponsibly, in my view, report matters that are grossly factually inaccurate.

I am pleased with the suggestion that ASIS should no longer continue to rely solely on the proposition that it will neither confirm or deny any particular allegation. The report suggested that the organisation should selectively from time to time background some of the journalists where they seek to be backgrounded and so kill off some of the more fanciful and mostly inaccurate things that they are preparing to write.

It goes without saying that, notwithstanding the accountability that is proposed in the report and that we have discussed in the debate so far, if intelligence operations are to remain effective, they need to be secret and known only by the agency conducting them. It is not possible to conduct intelligence in any other way. One of the important considerations for Australia is that we tend to place a great deal of reliance not just on ASIS, which is our overseas operation, but also on all intelligence services—we have a number of them—in terms of security for Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to a question was circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many pensioner concession cards for 1995 did his Department forward to persons who were not entitled to them.
(2) What steps did his Department take to recover the cards.
(3) How many cards were recovered.
(4) What is the estimated cost incurred by Commonwealth and State departments for benefits obtained by persons with concession cards to which they were not entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Pensioner Concession Cards for 1995 were issued at the end of 1994 to 2.6 million pensioners and older long term allowees in receipt of payment at 25 October 1994.

An estimated 37,700 persons (1.5% of the total group entitled to cards at 25 October 1994) were no longer entitled by the time the cards were all delivered in mid-December 1994. Of these, an estimated 12,600 had died in the interim period and the remainder had lost pension eligibility owing to income, employment, departure overseas or other reasons.

(2) When payment is cancelled, pensioners are advised that they cannot use their Pensioner Concession Card after the cancellation date, and are asked to destroy the card so that nobody can misuse it. Steps are not taken to recover cards but some cards are voluntarily returned.
Scope for misuse of cards to which people are no longer entitled is further reduced by data-matching facilities which provide:

a daily on-line data exchange between DSS and the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), which assists the HIC to ensure that Commonwealth pharmaceutical concessions are not supplied to persons who are no longer current cardholders; and

a Client Confirmation Service, which is widely used by State and local government concession providers, such as councils and electricity authorities, that provide regular concessions to many pensioners. These concession providers send computer tapes to DSS at regular intervals to confirm claimants' continuing eligibility for the card.
(3) See the answer to (2).

(4) The cost to the Commonwealth of possible misuse of pharmaceutical and other health concessions by people not entitled to them is not quantifiable, but is likely to be of a very low order owing to the use by Commonwealth health concession providers of the data-matching facilities.

Cards are issued to pensioners and allowees for the primary purpose of facilitating their access to the Commonwealth pharmaceutical and health benefits. For State instrumentalities that also use the card, the cost of possible misuse of cards in respect of some of the most valuable core concessions States provide to cardholders (rates, electricity, motor vehicle registration), though similarly unquantifiable, is also minimised by the providers' use of the data-matching facilities. The cost to the States of possible misuse in respect of State public transport and other concessions is unknown.
